summary: Paul Merson has reignited his row with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was brought on late in a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, but Townsend's stunning equaliser for England against Italy proved Merson wrong, leading him to admit his mistake. Despite Townsend hitting back on Twitter, any bad feeling between them seemed to have passed, yet Merson couldn't resist another dig at Townsend following the Tottenham draw.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. If Muto completes a move to Stamford Bridge this summer, he will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Ogane states that this interest is not connected to the £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who has an economics degree and has earned 11 caps for Japan, admits he hasn't decided yet about joining the Premier League title chasers, calling the offer an honor.

Babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers, according to a large-scale study. The research, published in Pediatrics, suggests that antibiotics might contribute to the obesity epidemic, as seen in the increased body mass in healthy children associated with antibiotic exposure before six months or repeated use during infancy. By two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese, with children who had taken antibiotics as young babies particularly likely to be overweight. The study didn't prove causation, but it may be because antibiotics kill gut bugs that normally feed on food, freeing up more for the body and possibly increasing appetite. The findings highlight the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, as their extended use has undesirable and unexpected consequences, potentially playing a role in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an event witnessed by hundreds of shocked tourists. The incident, caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell, saw the guard lose his footing, knock his bearskin, and drop his rifle before scrambling to his feet. The soldier, wearing full regalia, appeared embarrassed as he realized many people had seen the moment. It is thought that the slip occurred due to the metal protectors on his boots' soles. The Ministry of Defence did not comment on the young man falling over while doing his job.

A&E networks are remaking the epic miniseries "Roots," originally about an African-American slave and his descendants, which had a massive audience of over 100 million viewers in 1977. The new version will be simulcast by A&E, Lifetime, and History in 2016, drawing more from Alex Haley's classic novel and consulting scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The updated saga aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation, highlighting Kunta Kinte's story in a contemporary context, amidst events like Barack Obama's presidency and racial unrest in the U.S.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, is claiming that palace aides at Clarence House tried to force him into an orgy in January 1978 when he was 27. On his first day, he was pinned to a chair, groped by a male staff member, and threatened to keep quiet after the incident. Lawler left the job the same day, haunted by the ordeal for years. He later contacted palace officials again after inquiries into a VIP paedophile ring began, but his complaints were ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide was reportedly interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has stated that the Royal Household would work exhaustively and co-operatively with any police probe, as investigations continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video set to the theme from '90s television sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The clip, featuring them rapping as they drive, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. In the video, Melissa raps about their journey to parenthood, including the surprise of the pregnancy after trying to conceive for two months. At the end, they share a sonogram of their unborn child. The video was made so loved ones living far away could know about the baby, and its success was unexpected. Additionally, Melissa had earlier made a video capturing Jesse's reaction when he found out about the pregnancy after reading a tag on their dog.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind, featuring a gray jacket and skirt with a black zigzag applique, sold for $137,000 at auction. It was part of more than 150 items from the film offered by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. The ensemble, which faded from its original slate blue-gray to light gray, was used in key scenes, including when Scarlett meets Rhett Butler and during an attack in the shanty town. The dress was from the private collection of James Tumblin, who collected onscreen costumes and artifacts, and he had bought it for $20 when it was about to be thrown away. Other top selling items included a straw hat worn by Leigh, a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, and a black bonnet.

A two-year-old boy is recovering after falling into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo when his parents dangled him over the edge, causing him to slip and fall between 10 to 12ft into the pit. The child was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived, suffering minor bumps, bruises, and a leg injury but not being attacked by the animals. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, has been angled directly on a house's front door, despite not working for over two years. Fixed devices, including around 300 speed and traffic cameras using old technology, were switched off across the region in March 2013. Speed enforcement now relies on mobile camera units, fixed cameras on motorways, and traffic officers. Mystery surrounds who re-pointed the camera, but a Birmingham City Council spokesman stated they are aware and will take appropriate action, possibly removing it. There are no plans to include this camera in a new pilot using digital technology.

Usain Bolt will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas next month as part of the Jamaican team, with the event taking place on May 2 and 3. The six-time Olympic gold medallist expressed being fit, healthy, and ready to run, emphasizing his commitment to making the country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle noted the pleasure in having the world's fastest man run for Jamaica, expecting some sprint magic on the track. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed their dedication to Barcelona by supporting the club’s basketball side, attending an El Clasico match where Barca won 85-80 in the Euro League. They were joined by Neymar's sister, Rafaella. Despite the victory, Real Madrid remains top of their Euro League division by points difference. Prior to this, Neymar helped Brazil beat Chile 1-0, enduring brutal challenges. Before the international break, Barcelona had won their El Clasico to lead La Liga by four points. Neymar and his team-mates are set to return to La Liga, facing Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble of trophies.

Italy is dealing with a surge of desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with a total of 8,480 migrants rescued from Friday to Monday. The Italian coast guard received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. There are fears that a ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean, potentially leaving 400 missing, but the coast guard has not confirmed this incident or found evidence of it. There has been an upsurge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with an increase in rescues by the Italian Coast Guard. The International Organization for Migration reports that Italy registered over 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015, and about 2,000 were rescued at sea during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers, with some captains and crews abandoning the ships.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is unsure why Alexis Sanchez chose the Emirates Stadium over Anfield but is glad the Chile forward will be playing for his side instead of against them for Liverpool. Sanchez, after Barcelona decided to let him leave, was convinced to continue his career under Wenger's guidance, making an instant impact in English football with 19 goals so far. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been leverage during negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to the Nou Camp. He also plays down any talk of a potential summer transfer for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling, despite the Reds' loss to Manchester United. Wenger is impressed by Brendan Rodgers' development of his team following the sale of Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome, aiming to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, who recently finished his Team Sky career, views the Hour Record as a holy grail for cyclists. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins hopes for a capacity crowd to spur him on, with tickets available from April 19, and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, a twice French Open champion, described her struggle to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as a real 'eye-opener,' indicating she is not as ready for the claycourt season as she thought. Despite prevailing in their singles match with a score of 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, Williams and Alison Riske were defeated in the doubles rubber by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, leading to the US being beaten 3-2 and relegated to World Group II. Williams acknowledged the need to adjust her mindset, stating she is playing like she's on hard court when she is not. The defeat blotted an otherwise flawless Fed Cup record, with the US now facing a battle to return to the elite nations next year.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, with vice president Matias Patanian stating they dream of Falcao and that the doors are open. Falcao, who previously spent eight years with the Argentine side before leaving for Porto in 2009, has struggled on loan at United, scoring just four Premier League goals. It remains uncertain if United will keep him or if he will return to parent club Monaco. Despite his club struggles, Falcao has been in good form for his country, scoring three times in two games to equal Colombia’s all-time goalscoring record.

Ella Henderson, an X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features the singer in various hairstyles against a blurred city background, including a wavy style and a tousled half-ponytail. It was fused by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring her latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson expressed excitement about working with the brand, as it is a product she uses regularly.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, a man shot dead by police last month, are in shock after a billboard featuring the officer who pulled the trigger, Pablo Torres, was erected in Kenosham, Wisconsin. Siler was fatally shot after arming himself with a weapon following a confrontation with Torres, who is currently on leave pending an investigation. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, has been called 'disrespectful' by Siler's family and friends, who want it taken down. The police association claims the billboard was meant to thank the community for its support, stating that recent incidents have impacted many people, including the officer and police department.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan, with three militants also killed by Iranian forces. The attack was claimed by a militant group called Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group that has targeted Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian officials have asked Pakistani authorities to catch the surviving assailants, and the Pakistani government condemned the attack as an "act of terrorism," stating that security agencies are investigating and will apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan after the incident.

Japan's government top military official, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani, revealed that the Air Self Defense Force had never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object, responding to a query from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Nakatani explained that when the ASDF detects indications of an unidentified flying object, it scrambles fighter jets if necessary and makes visual observation, sometimes finding birds or other flying objects but no UFOs believed to have come from outside Earth. Inoki, known for his wrestling background and political endeavors, asked about aircraft being scrambled for extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors, prompting Nakatani's response. This exchange is not the first time Japanese politicians have discussed implications of visitors from another planet, with then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba pondering legal ramifications in 2007.

A passenger, Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He had stood on the rim, worried about the seat not being clean, and the porcelain toilet tipped over, shattering and cutting him. The injured man called his travelling companions for help, as he was too embarrassed to shout. He received several dozens of stitches in the hospital. Initially, he confessed to squatting but later changed his story to the police, possibly to avoid paying compensation, claiming he was sitting when the toilet gave way. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and reminded people that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

A Pennsylvania man, Kevin Rebbie, 56, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom, which police traced back to him. Rebbie allegedly sexually abused the girl in her home over a four-year period, starting when she was nine and continuing until she was thirteen, and filmed her and others with the hidden camera. The investigation revealed that he uploaded 41 videos, including footage of the girl and others while they used the bathroom, some showing victims showering and close-up images of children's genitalia. He faces charges such as aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, purchasing the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images featuring po-faced teenagers next to their fathers leaping into the air. In each picture, the daughter looks directly into the camera smiling while her father pulls a dramatic pose. The images are part of a book that roughly translates into Daughter and Salary Man, allowing fathers to express their fun side by being 'a hero jumping the sky, enfold(ing) strong excitement and hope.' The fathers are seen in sharply dressed suits, making energetic poses despite their age, with some older fathers showing slightly pained expressions. The pictures see families posing in front of various Japanese landmarks, and they are already drumming up plenty of interest online for their curious nature.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director is a big talking point, but attention has shifted to the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, appearing in a range of emotions, posed for the Surrey team photo before the new campaign, looking in deep thought yet jovial. His presence at the KIA Oval event, ahead of Surrey's campaign start, marks a step closer to a potentially sensational return to the England set-up. Downton's sacking has paved the way for Pietersen, who was controversially axed in 2014, to rejoin the international team. With England aiming to regain the urn this summer, Pietersen has rejoined Surrey to force his way back into the Test set-up.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, under relegation threat, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially fired after a poor run, he was reinstated by owner Angelo Massone, who decided to give the coaching staff another chance. However, Ze Maria angered Massone again following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, leaving Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points from safety. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco team-mate, believes Falcao must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United, even though he was not happy in France. Falcao, who moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan, has struggled to reach the heights he achieved before a serious knee injury. Despite United needing to pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent, they are unlikely to do so, as Falcao has only scored four goals all season. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played and participated in the Champions League, but he may need more atmosphere, as he was not feeling well there.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy, wearing a 'distinctive' cartoon mask. The offender, described as 'very tall' and seen in a fluoro orange sweatshirt on security footage, took the dairy's till and about $1500 in cash on Saturday. A man in the mask demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter, prompting police to be called to the Union St dairy in east Christchurch. The masked man threw the cash register to the ground and fled with the till drawer. Police report no signs of weapons used and that the robber remains at large, asking for anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested again after another 15-year-old pupil accused her of having sex on two consecutive nights in January in her car. This follows her first arrest on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old, where she admitted to kissing the pupil and allowing him to touch her breasts. After the initial arrest, she was suspended and placed on administrative leave. The second accusation came to light when a school police officer learned of a possible relationship with another boy, leading to her being booked into Irving County Jail for the second time, later released on a $50,000 bail. The Irving school district stated they took immediate and appropriate action, preventing her from working with students or being present on any school property.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times online. The incident was witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston, who described the crocodile holding the dog for ages without moving. The dog belonged to the local bike shop's owner and was likely curious when it approached the water's edge. The crocodile, from a sanctuary up the river, was seen in the marina, and the event shocked onlookers. Social media users reacted in horror, with some expressing dislike for crocodiles. In Puerto Vallarta, crocodiles are common, living in the area's mangroves and even being spotted on the resort's golf course.

Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, which has left them battling to stay up. Initially targeting 10 wins to survive, Bruce now hopes 'nine or eight might be enough.' Hull has six games left, including tough fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to several long-term injuries to key players, such as Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Meanwhile, Southampton's James Ward-Prowse scored a penalty, and Ronald Koeman addressed issues with team rules after Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty when Ward-Prowse was the first-choice taker.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom after he let pupils change their exam answers, invalidating his whole school's SATs results. He asked pupils to make changes to the national curriculum tests for 11-year-olds at Mitton Manor Primary School, even altering some answers himself before the papers were sent off. This led to an investigation by the local education authority, which found that some pupils had changed answers outside exam conditions and that Guffick had done the same. As a result, the Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the entire school. Guffick admitted the allegations, accepted it amounted to unacceptable professional conduct, and was forced to give up his job. The panel, run by the National College for Teaching and Leadership, said his conduct was dishonest but fell short of fraud. Paul Heathcote, acting for Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, banned Guffick from the classroom for at least two years, agreeing with the panel's recommendation of a prohibition order. Guffick has shown remorse and insight and was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has not played much at the club but is happy off the pitch with his wife, Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots. They tied the knot in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together, having dated since 2012. Lindegaard, who has struggled for minutes in his career at United, made just 19 league appearances in five seasons and is now third-choice with David de Gea and Victor Valdes ahead of him. Despite his lack of impact on the pitch, he is enjoying his time with Beqiri, who regularly posts modelling photos on Instagram.

The glowing blue letters that once lit the Bronx from above Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction, with only a Sotheby's employee bidding $260,000 to jump start the bidding. The letters, expected to bring in $300,000 to $600,000, were owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who bought them after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson had hoped a new generation would own and enjoy the icon but bought the letters 'on a lark,' joking about possibly getting ahead of himself with their size. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, auctioned off, raked in a winning bid of $112,500, despite being estimated at only $20,000 to $30,000.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide and pictured with shisha pipes. Although neither will be disciplined, Rodgers wants them to learn from the chastening week and draw a line under the matter. He emphasized the importance of understanding what can and cannot be done as elite sportspersons, considering their responsibilities. Rodgers also mentioned that Steven Gerrard is available for the FA Cup semi-final with Aston Villa, but he has not decided on giving Gerrard an immediate recall, focusing instead on steering Liverpool into their first FA Cup final of his reign.

Mesut Ozil, the Arsenal playmaker, returned to London after the international break and seemed to be enjoying his home comforts, posting a picture of himself relaxing with his dog. He was in fine form as Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier and is now looking ahead to the Premier League encounter with Liverpool. Ozil missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle through illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. He has been performing well on the pitch, with four assists and three goals since January, and claims to be finally adjusting to English football, stating he fits in 'perfectly' despite the demanding schedule.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that there are no plans to replace Luis Enrique, emphasizing that the club is 'very happy' with him. Despite speculation about a potential replacement in the summer, Bartomeu refuted these claims, noting that Enrique, who took charge last summer, has impressed with his performance. The president mentioned that Enrique has a contract until 2016 and highlighted that Barcelona is still capable of winning three trophies, going into the final stretch of the season.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, providing a lift after their FA Cup heartache. His new deal, expected to be worth around £100,000-a-week, will run until the summer of 2020. Henderson, who had 14 months remaining on his current contract, is set to be the third big player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to agree a contract extension, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He has been one of the most improved players under Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. Henderson could replace Steven Gerrard as Liverpool captain when the 34-year-old departs this summer.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering bringing him back in the summer. He signed a three-year contract when moving from Atletico last July but has struggled to secure the left back position at Stamford Bridge. Luis expressed happiness at Chelsea and emphasized his desire to remain. The focus now turns to the Premier League title run-in, with Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho urging the team to stay focused and win every game. Luis also mentioned the difficulty of the remaining nine games but believes the team is prepared to handle the challenging situation.

Nathan Hughes had his ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal after an outcry. Initially suspended for three matches and shown a red card, the disciplinary panel had ruled his knee collision with North's head as reckless. However, in a stunning twist, the ban was thrown out as the appeal by Wasps was upheld, with the panel concluding no act of foul play occurred, as the incident was accidental. North was left unconscious, marking the third time he had been knocked out in two months, and has been advised to take a month off from playing. Hughes is now free to return to action but is not in the match-day squad for Wasps’ Aviva Premiership trip and is unlikely to play again until April 26.

A fiery sunset was observed in Washington, catching the attention of Seattle native Tim Durkan, who photographed and shared the event. These stunning sunsets were caused by raging wildfires in parts of Siberia, started by farmers burning grass in their fields but growing out of control due to strong winds on April 14. The fires destroyed dozens of villages, and the lingering smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest. The intense red sunset is a result of smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange to penetrate unfiltered. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the reddish hue of these sunsets will fade.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. Police later found the car, returned it to her, but it had been modified with red rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to thank the car thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle, sharing a photo of her and the car. She is now getting the vehicle professionally cleaned due to a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Additionally, she is creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, the man who located her car and notified police.

Manchester City players could lose £500,000-a-man in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club has incentivised contracts for star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure to stay within financial fairplay requirements. If City do not reach the group stages of Europe's top competition, they will miss out on a big payday, with around £12 million resting on reaching their European target. The team is in fourth place, and their European hopes are in the balance after a defeat in the Manchester derby. The top three finishers in the Premier League qualify automatically for the Champions League, with the fourth-place team needing to win a qualifying round.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring a delightful free-kick to secure the win. The match, featuring a significant number of English and Mancunian players, was part of the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. United's victory leaves them two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury-ravaged City have now lost both matches in the series. The game showcased talents on both sides that may deserve their chance in the coming years, as it was high on skill and commitment.

England's Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon claimed his 147th cap. Hart, who recently earned his 50th international cap, expressed admiration for Buffon, stating he is an inspiration and someone he looks up to. Hart, still learning his game, acknowledged the challenge of reaching Buffon's caps total but wants to continue playing well for his club and country to add to his international appearances.

Mexican restaurant Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. This move includes a nine per cent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, depending on distance and demand. Chipotle had previously turned down collaboration offers with third-party delivery services but has now given Postmates the green light. The app uses independent contractors, similar to Uber taxis. Additionally, Chipotle has attracted celebrity customers, with presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton being spotted in their restaurants. Other franchises, like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also looking to cash in on the delivery market through various partnerships and programs.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Bill and Denise Richard, are urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the 2013 bombings. They argue that pursuing the death penalty could prolong their family's anguish through years of appeals, reliving the most painful day when their 8-year-old son, Martin, was murdered, and their daughter, Jane, was severely injured. The Richards support the Department of Justice in taking the death penalty off the table in exchange for Tsarnaev spending the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waiving all rights to appeal. They stress that they are only speaking for themselves and believe it is time to turn the page, end the anguish, and look toward a better future.

A custom-built Boeing 747 has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, featuring bedrooms, multiple lounges, an onboard restaurant, and a dining room connected to a kitchen. The jumbo jet, which cost £400 million after three years of customization, was designed to fit the owner's specifications and can accommodate dozens of guests. It includes a large dining area, a lounge, a 'state room,' and an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds on the top deck. The plane also has a conference room for meetings, a main suite resembling a top hotel, and areas for guests to relax, offering a far more glitzy experience than first class on commercial flights.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The launch was successful, but the company's attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket landing too hard and tipping over. This follows a previous attempt in January where the rocket hit at an angle and exploded. SpaceX aims to master sea landings to eventually land rockets on the ground, seeking to reduce costs by reusing rockets. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station, including research equipment and an espresso maker, and later return with experiments, trash, and other items before splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This marks the sixth SpaceX mission to the International Space Station, with Tuesday's launch being the second attempt after Monday's was scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. She collaborated with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the 'ultimate wedding,' which includes tying the knot at the chapel inside the Westgate Hotel on April 23. The winning duo will also receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla emphasized that the chapel is not a joke and has been involved in its look and feel, part of a permanent Graceland exhibit outside Elvis's Memphis home. Couples must submit a video or photos with an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side could catch Manchester City in the Barclays Premier League, despite being four points behind. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, equalling a record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring with fine skill, and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal after capitalizing on a defensive mistake. Henderson expressed that after finding winning form again following poor results, Liverpool can pile pressure on City.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in a key Serie A match for Champions League places. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute with a clinical counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis was crucial in saving shots by Napoli in the second half. The win moved second-place Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. Meanwhile, Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and security was tight for the game, with no reports of problems.

Doncaster Rovers have had an uninspiring season, remaining in mid-table mediocrity in League One. Their match against Fleetwood Town, who were looking towards the beach as their play-off hopes faded, resulted in a goalless draw that tested the patience of even the most ardent fans. The media team struggled to compile highlights for the club's YouTube channel, ultimately creating a very short video—just 27 seconds with 14 seconds of match action—showcasing the kick off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, which he captures on camera. The fish interacts with him by allowing him to gently cup it with his hand, stroke it, and give it a massage, often returning to be touched again. The fish swims up his arm and circles his fingers, showing sociable behavior. Mr. Giroux noticed this after removing two other fish that were bullying his pet, and he started feeding it by hand, eventually leading the fish to enjoy being stroked. The fish becomes frustrated if not played with daily, and Mr. Giroux spends at least 15 minutes each day massaging and playing with it. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes has a reputation as a fiery character in the England cricket team, having previously broken his wrist by punching a locker. After a clash with Marlon Samuels, he responded positively following a chat with coach Peter Moores, showing that his aggression can be channeled in the right way. England wants to ensure they do not quash his natural exuberance and desire to take someone on, as long as it is controlled and results in runs and wickets. The team aims to have Stokes play as much as possible to help him reach his full potential, alongside other exciting cricketers like Chris Jordan, as they grow into the international game.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium, set for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, has been declared a 33,000 sell-out. Both teams are top in Group B with 11 points from five games, with Belgium ranked fourth in the world. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel, featuring a free-kick by Gareth Bale, has raised expectations for them to qualify for the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales noted overwhelming demand for tickets, leading to the sell-out. The Wales squad prefers the Cardiff City Stadium over the Millennium Stadium, despite speculation about a venue change, as UEFA rules prevent altering the venue within 120 days of the scheduled date.

England coach John Peacock has announced the squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the Young Lions are the defending champions and have a 100 per cent record in qualifying. They are placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, opening their campaign against Italy on May 7. The squad includes talented young players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, with Willock being called up for the first time. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have earned a recall after missing the Elite Round qualifiers. Their other matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing Anderlecht teenager Evangelos Patoulidis, a 14-year-old playmaker considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth. He has drawn attention from Arsenal and Barcelona, having previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at 12 to continue his studies. City have discussed with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to agree on a compensation package, as Manuel Pellegrini aims to build for the future by acquiring this hot property.

A man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, who was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. Her body was discovered after the London Ambulance Service was called to Romily Court on March 28, and she was pronounced dead at the scene with injuries to her head and neck. The 23-year-old arrested has been bailed and must return to a police station for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing to anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death, as police aim to solve the case.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, was devastated to discover that a family friend, Jamie, had stolen £207 set aside for a grave stone for one of her babies, Daniel James. She appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show, accusing Jamie, a long-term chum and convicted burglar who lives with her and her partner, of taking the money. After a lie detector test revealed Jamie's deception, Dawn burst into tears and stormed off. The stolen amount was intended for a £500 grave stone, and Jamie had sent a Facebook message confessing to taking the money but blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed feeling betrayed, as the money was meant to show how much her child was loved.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, with most being women and children, followed by the ill or elderly, as reported by officials. The Peshmerga force received the freed Yazidis and sent them to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, but the exact motivation wasn't immediately clear. Previously, ISIS had released other Yazidis, including children and the elderly, since attacking their towns last year. The group's actions, including slaughtering hundreds and reports of rape and enslavement of female captives, have caused significant humanitarian crises, especially after the conquest of Sinjar. An international coalition responded with airdropped supplies, rescues, and airstrikes targeting ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham sensation who has broken into the first team and England's side, is being animated off the pitch as well, following his animated celebrations on it. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A clever new animation by Copa90 features some of Kane's best goals and celebrations, using still photographs to create an animated effect. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', highlights his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his goal on England debut. It has been released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane is up against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right person to lead Liverpool forward despite a season with no trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, speaking after collecting a Beacon Award for his community work, stated that Rodgers' future shouldn't be determined by one game and that the manager, along with the players and staff, should focus on next season to go further, possibly winning a trophy and getting back into the top four. He emphasized the need for right signings to make a difference, as Liverpool are seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport, deemed a security risk by airport security who described as 'over-zealous' by his father, Phil. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was packed in his hand luggage for a flight to Lanzarote. Security officers took exception to the toy on X-ray machines, demanding it be handed over and performing a patting down of the child. Phil criticized the checks as 'ludicrous' and the staff's reaction, explaining they left the toy to avoid missing their flight. After returning from the holiday, the family bought James a replacement toy gun off eBay. East Midlands Airport apologized, stating their priority is passenger safety and that regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items, such as replica or model guns.

A lonely man in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife, outlining his requirements for the ideal partner. He details that the successful candidate must love pets, enjoy the outdoors, be a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit and attractive, reliable, honest, and loyal, with skills in being good around the house, having good hands, cooking, and being great in bed. The man, identified as "Rich," describes himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, not into drinking, smoking, or drugs, and someone who likes traveling, the outdoors, sports, and fishing. He owns property, makes great money, and is successful, promising his potential partner benefits and that all reasonable offers will be considered. The hopeless romantic also states that former partners need not apply.

Greg Dyke, Football Association chairman, has received support from five former England managers as he aims to implement changes, including increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12. The proposals also redefine 'home-grown' to mean training in England for three years before the age of 18. Dyke faces opposition from the Premier League, and the former managers warn that blocking the proposals could harm the English game, risking England falling behind leading football nations and making it harder to end the long wait to win the World Cup. They argue that the pool of English talent at the top level is shrinking, and with emerging players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, the key issue is providing opportunity.

Demelza Poldark is now the proud mother to the show’s latest addition, and fans will see Ross Poldark lovingly gaze at their new baby daughter in the upcoming episode. However, the timeline of the pregnancy is questionable, as it jumps from the announcement in the previous episode to Demelza being eight months pregnant and then giving birth shortly after, with the last month of her pregnancy passing in less than the blink of an eye. This fast-paced portrayal is reminiscent of a previous pregnancy in the show, and it didn’t go unnoticed by fans, who have commented on the swift progression.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his players to focus on their own job and remain cool, advising them to ignore their relegation rivals during the run-in. Despite a mini-revival with back-to-back wins, including Jamie Vardy's injury-time winner against West Brom, Leicester is still bottom of the table. Pearson emphasizes that their future is in their own hands and that they need to ensure their run-in is as desired, rather than getting involved in anything apart from their own games. He also mentions the importance of being in touch and cautions against people becoming overly optimistic.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest migration of a mammal, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from her primary feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Bruce Mate, the lead author of the study, suggests that Varvara's trip might indicate more about the whale than just her swimming ability, as she visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales. Initially thought to be an endangered western whale, her impressive navigation could imply that some western gray whales are actually eastern grays, prompting a need to reconsider past genetic differentiation studies.

Residents on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island experienced an unexpected change when 1,000ft of seabed emerged overnight on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, rising as high as 50ft from the sea surface. Geologists believe this land swell resulted from a landslide, caused by melting ice and snow making a section of land drop and pivot the underwater area into the air. The new stretch of land, measuring roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, came as a complete surprise to locals, with no indication of movement, sounds, or tremors. Authorities do not expect it to expand further and note it is different from earthquakes, not related to the recent 7.8-magnitude earthquake in the Kathmandu Valley.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims that he is set to leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, reiterating his love for the club, the city, and his teammates. Despite a recent falling out with his boss Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League clash against Chelsea, Van der Wiel insists he is happy in Paris and making no plans to leave, stating there is no reason for him to depart and expressing a desire to sign a new contract. The Parisians are linked with Barcelona star Dani Alves, raising questions about whether Van der Wiel has any choice in staying with the club.

Carlos Tevez has been told to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his deal with the Serie A champions not expiring until the end of next season, Tevez wishes to leave this summer, shocking the club. Boca has confirmed they are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old, with president Daniel Angelici stressing that contract termination with Juventus is necessary first. Although Juventus are reluctant to lose the league's top scorer, they have accepted his desire to leave and are identifying potential replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, states that any move would not affect his Argentina future, emphasizing that it doesn't matter whether he plays at Juventus or Boca.

Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, ripped the left trouser leg of his grey garments during an exciting Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, leaving his underwear on show. This happened as Bayern led their opponents, Porto, 5-0 at half-time, eventually winning 6-1 and booking a place in the semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Guardiola joked about needing to buy new trousers for the next match.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were first flown to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man also suffered hand lacerations, while two females escaped injuries. Emergency crews rescued a person trapped in their vehicle, and the Rescue 500 helicopter airlifted patients. The affected highway stretch has been closed, with diversions in place south of Fernvale, and police expect it to be closed for a few hours.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil is excited about his new Apple Watch, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider, as the Premier League crunch time approaches with Arsenal hosting Chelsea. Ozil, who received the timepiece after visiting an Apple store, is expected to start for Arsene Wenger's side at the Emirates Stadium. Meanwhile, Arsenal trail the Blues by 10 points with six league games remaining, but have been boosted by Jack Wilshere's return. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness record is the key factor holding him back from reaching his potential, emphasizing the importance of staying fit to play a big role for the club.

Referee Mark Clattenburg has been assigned to officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford, despite having sent off three players from both teams this season. City captain Vincent Kompany was dismissed for two bookable offences during Belgium's match, suspending him for the Wales game. Clattenburg has sent off two players this season in the Premier League, both from United, including Tyler Blackcett and Luke Shaw. The derby could determine who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea, with United having moved a point above their rivals after a shock loss to Crystal Palace. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter has risked being drawn into a race row by accusing the Queensland Government of seeing embattled MP Billy Gordon as 'a little black puppet on a string,' suggesting they assumed Gordon would quit after domestic violence accusations and admitting his criminal past. Katter, of Lebanese descent, stated he has faced racist attitudes from major parties and sympathized with Gordon's position. The statement has sparked criticism on social media, with users questioning his terminology. Katter defended the term, linking it to his personal experiences and dark complexion, and cited federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of independents becoming government puppets, vowing Gordon would not make that mistake. Gordon, forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party, announced he will remain in the parliament as an independent, causing chaos for the government's razor-thin majority.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, who was born with cerebral palsy, is using dancing to tackle her disability and positively influence others. She creates videos, such as one where she dances to Taylor Swift's Shake It Off, aiming to challenge stereotypes and inspire people to think before judging. Dayna wants to change how people with disabilities are represented in television, film, and the fashion industry, emphasizing that she is pretty much the same as everyone else despite doing things a little differently. Her motivation is to turn any negativity around her disability into something positive, hoping to inspire others or at least raise a smile. Additionally, she has started motivational speaking at local schools in the Chicago area.

Orlando City, an MLS side with a big Latin-American fanbase, have shown interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid and has been struggling. Hernandez could be a popular addition, as eight European sides, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also interested. Meanwhile, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted attention from clubs like Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a car at a South Los Angeles gas station and set it on fire after the driver got into an argument with them while pumping gas. The suspects attempted to carjack the man, pulled out a gun, and he took off running. They then took the gas tank and started spraying, covering the white Dodge Charger in gasoline and lighting it ablaze while there were two passengers inside. No one was injured, but the car was completely ruined, with its entire front end torched. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson, and surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. He admitted to these misdeeds through an agreement, pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. The agreement requires Manuel to prove that circumstances surrounding the license revocation, including bartering sex for services, no longer exist before he can resume practicing. Despite the accusations, Manuel received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com, with three survey responses giving him a perfect five out of five stars.

A Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace north of Poland, with the United States complaining that the Russian pilot's actions were "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed. The Pentagon stated the incident occurred in international airspace, and a U.S. official denied the Russian claim that the plane's transponder was off. The U.S. plans to file a petition through diplomatic channels with Russia. This is not the first such incident, as a year ago a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, which U.S. officials called one of the most dangerous close passes in decades.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot, specifically from the Marriott Springhill Suites, just days before President Obama visited Utah. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was ripped out of the agent's car window, with police believing the thief used a rope and another vehicle's momentum to break the case's handle free. The theft occurred overnight, and the agent also reported stolen gear, a backpack, and clothing. The rifle has not been recovered, while the agent's belongings were found at a Residence Inn across the street. The Secret Service was notified before Obama's visit, but it is unclear if the theft prompted increased security.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in the dining room of his home on Mugga Way, Red Hill, Canberra in July 2012. A jury has heard that Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and stated there was evidence of his declining state of mind before and during the incident, with his brain compromised by dementia and alcohol leading to a confused state. The trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet and fluctuating mood during triple 0 calls suggested his mental confusion. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez had to defend another penalty fiasco after Ross Barkley missed from the spot in their 1-0 win against Burnley. Barkley took the 10th-minute kick instead of Leighton Baines, who has a strong record with penalties. This situation recalled a previous incident where Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines and missed. Martinez insisted Barkley was within his rights to request penalty-taking duties, stating he is happy to have multiple players who can take penalties depending on how they feel. Despite Barkley's well-struck effort, Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton saved it. Fortunately, Mirallas later scored the only goal of the game.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, with the cruise line suggesting it appears to be a murder-suicide. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating. The ship is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and the cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers after knocking on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has started successfully as coach of Curacao in World Cup qualifying. The Caribbean island team advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament after drawing 2-2 in a second-leg match at Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Curacao won 2-1 on Saturday in Willemstad, with the first-round encounter going to extra time until Charlton Vicento scored in the 87th minute. They will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has won all major European competitions, believes keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be as significant as winning a trophy, despite the team being seven points adrift at the bottom with only eight games left. He refuses to give up, stating that saving Leicester feels like another cup and that they have chances to win matches. Cambiasso, who signed for Leicester in the summer, is convinced they can avoid the drop and has quickly become a key player, expressing happiness in the East Midlands and the possibility of staying beyond his current one-year-deal.

A 23-year-old mother-of-two, named Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children by her mother, Debbie, because she refuses to stop drinking and partying. Gemma has two children under five, whom she handed over to Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie is threatening to prevent Gemma from seeing the children after discovering her penchant for legal high, MKat, and suspecting her of stealing, including an iPad from one of the children, which Gemma admits to selling to fund her party lifestyle. Debbie, who has been caring for the children after social services threatened to take them away, says Gemma isn't fit enough to have them and doesn't care, as she gave up about four months after having them and dumped the babies on her. Now, Debbie is preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because she can't trust her not to pinch their possessions.

During a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Eden Hazard scored a goal that gave Chelsea a 1-0 lead. The build-up involved Chelsea captain John Terry making a strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao, which the Sky Sports punditry team, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, believed to be a foul. They agreed that play should have been stopped for Terry's rough tackle, with Souness noting a forearm smash and elbow in Falcao's back as the reason for the fall. Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao, and Redknapp admitted that while Falcao could have stayed on his feet, Terry's challenge shouldn't have gone unpunished.

Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but everyone on board, including her, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated. The fire occurred after the bus stopped due to a rear tire blowout and burst into flames once everyone had gotten off. Michael Barnett captured dramatic video of the incident, and Scott posted a photo of the charred bus on Instagram, thanking God for their safety and noting that the fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except her Bible. The band's two other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

A Scottish scientist, Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University, is exploring the use of space lasers to power homes by converting sunlight into energy through satellites covered in mirrors. These satellites would orbit the Earth, harvesting sunlight and converting it into laser light, which is then shot back down using semi-conductors. The goal is to boost energy received by solar panels, potentially making solar power viable in Scotland or restoring power to disaster areas. Unlike movie depictions, these lasers won't be powerful enough to blind a pigeon or blow up a planet. Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about who might control the satellites. Separately, Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system for the International Space Station to target and clear small pieces of space debris, using powerful pulses to push it into Earth’s atmosphere to burn up, but this also isn't weaponizable.

A predatory convicted paedophile, Stephen Munden, 54, with a fanatical obsession with young girls, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit. He was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, and is described as about 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, with dark hair, possibly having shaved off his beard. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act following his sentence last August for sexual offences, including sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He was also found guilty of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. Officers have launched a manhunt to locate him, as he is subject to a hospital order and suffers from learning difficulties.

V. Stiviano has lost a significant amount, as a Los Angeles judge ordered her to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts from Donald Sterling, following a lawsuit by his wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. Shelly accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men, claiming that Donald used the couple's money to buy her luxury items like a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano countered that there was nothing wrong with receiving the gifts. The court decision was seen as a victory for the Sterling family, setting a precedent for an injured spouse to recover damages from the recipient of such gifts. Donald Sterling's downfall came after an audio recording surfaced where he chastised Stiviano for posting pictures with African-Americans, leading to his ban from the NBA, a $2.5 million fine, and the termination of his ownership rights in the franchise.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer dealings and urged the club to purchase a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and top striker to have a chance of winning the Barclays Premier League title. He specifically questioned whether Arsenal can win the league with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker, despite Giroud scoring 14 league goals this season. Henry cited Chelsea's signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of what Arsenal needs to do.

A young woman subjected to years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn has shared with a court the severe impact it had on her life. Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child, did not look at her as she spoke in Sydney's District Court. The woman expressed fear for her future relationships, stating that Van Ryn stole her right to share her body with someone for the first time. She didn't know the abuse was wrong and only broke her silence after learning he had been caught, later attempting to take her own life. She worries about how the abuse will affect her relations with men and has suffered depression since age 14, being hospitalised for self-harm and attempted suicide.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is feeling 'better and better' as he prepares to return after more than a year out due to a serious knee injury. His progress was stunted, and he has not featured for the first team since the Champions League last-16 second leg against Bayern Munich in March 2014. Gnabry played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading, marking his second 90-minute game in a week, and is now over his injury worries, looking forward to the next game.

A young accountant, Jacob Phillips, fell down a 70ft cliff to his death after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. He had caught the cab home after a night out with friends in December but didn’t have enough cash to pay for it. An inquest heard he ran from the driver, who gave chase at the seaside town of Penarth, South Wales. Phillips leapt over a fence in the dark and was found dead at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating it is likely he became disorientated and there is no evidence he knew the danger of the sheer drop.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer’s passport delay fiasco have not received compensation, despite managers at the passport agency receiving up to £3,500 in bonuses as they made a £42 million profit during the chaos. Ministers refused a blanket refund for desperate families who paid extra to rush their travel documents, with many missing trips. Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, expressed astonishment at the low number of compensation cases, noting that only 2,191 applications were approved, with an average payout of £92.68. The Passport Office could not disclose how many claims were rejected, and Ministers rejected a demand for compensation, citing it would create a precedent.

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, has remained unchanged since the 1930s and is now up for sale with original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro jars of popular food. The semi-detached property, untouched for over 80 years, includes the original bathroom, kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. It has a guide price of between £200,000 and £250,000, with some upgrades like double glazing, but auctioneers believe the potential renovation costs might deter developers. The house could be a perfect family home for those passionate about antiques and will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He remained the team's starting quarterback for the rest of the season, leading the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, although they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and it was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and around Colchester, Essex, attended the Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. The band's debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. Drawing influences from various music genres, Blur released their self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success. Albarn's debut solo studio album, Everyday Robots, co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014. It featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as sampling several rants by Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. As the capital, it hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their debut extended play, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American BAFTA-nominated screenwriter.

Shooter is a 2007 film that follows Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. There is also a TV series version where Ryan Phillippe stars as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is coaxed back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, all carried out by his group at his instruction. He also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After being charged with these crimes, recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his acting career in television and made his film debut in Taps (1981). He gained critical attention for roles in crime dramas like At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way. Penn became a prominent leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and a Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received two more Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, often called "The Don," was an Australian cricketer and is widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. After his retirement, he maintained a pre-eminent position in the game by serving as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.
L.A. Reid has held various leadership roles, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Morse code is a method of transmitting text information through on-off tones, lights, or clicks, understandable by a skilled listener or observer without special equipment. Compared to voice, it is less sensitive to poor signal conditions and remains comprehensible to humans without a decoding device. Many amateur radio repeaters identify with Morse, even when used for voice communications. In emergencies, it can be sent by improvised methods that are easily keyed on and off, making it a simple and versatile telecommunication method.

Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley, was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer, living from 12 October 1875 to 1 December 1947.
Poldark is a British-American drama television series that was first broadcast on BBC One on 8 March 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, released on 20 October 1995, stars Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol. The film was shot in India, London, and Switzerland, from September 1994 to August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth, born on 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director. Tim Roth, born on December 6, 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and only remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band, Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and they had three children together.

Sean Penn has won two Academy Awards for his roles in the mystery drama Mystic River (2003) and the biopic Milk (2008). He gained critical attention for roles in crime dramas like At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). Penn became a prominent leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received additional Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001) before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River. His fourth feature film, Into the Wild (2007), garnered critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

Volcanic outgassing likely created the primordial atmosphere and ocean, which contained almost no oxygen and was toxic to most modern life. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed, allowing liquid water to exist on the surface. Plate tectonics continues to shape Earth's oceans, continents, and the species they harbor. The biosphere, now dominated by human activity, produces significant effects on the atmosphere and other Earth surface systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, productive soils, and clean air and water. Water covers 71% of the Earth's surface.
Nuuk is the capital and largest city of Greenland and the municipality of Sermersooq.

How to Train Your Dragon 2 is written and directed by Dean DeBlois, featuring the voices of Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig. The entire voice cast from the first film returned, with Cate Blanchett and Djimon Hounsou joining to voice Valka and Drago, respectively.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson, and David Hyde Pierce. The film serves as a pastiche of sex comedies popular in the era it is set, particularly those starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson, such as Pillow Talk, Lover Come Back, and Send Me No Flowers. Additionally, there is a Down with Love TV series that was first broadcast in Taiwan on free-to-air China Television (CTV) and cable TV Gala Television (GTV).
Paris (Paris Hilton album) incorporates elements of other genres, such as reggae, soul, and pop rock, in its production.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman, starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. It features several actors in their first significant film roles, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold. Additionally, Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton appeared early in their careers.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song "Love or Lust," featured in Bill Duke's film Deep Cover, and for singing choruses to classic West Coast rap songs like Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride."
About 55 percent of undergraduates and 60 percent overall at the University of Mississippi come from Mississippi, with 23 percent being minorities. International students hail from 90 nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet -- Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy starred in a main role as Jenny Matrix in the hit web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, she co-starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime dark comedy-drama series, Unreal. She is also starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren was an American politician and the eighth President of the United States, serving from 1837 to 1841. A member of the Democratic Party, he held other senior roles, including eighth Vice President and tenth Secretary of State, both under Andrew Jackson. Van Buren was a major supporter and organizer for Jackson in the 1828 election, also running for Governor of New York to boost Jackson's campaign. After being elected, Van Buren resigned as governor after two months to become Jackson's Secretary of State. In 1831, following his resignation as Secretary of State, which helped Jackson resolve the Petticoat affair, Jackson gave Van Buren a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is home to Rutgers University - Camden, originally founded as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and the Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States, being the tenth most populous and having the 11th most extensive total area, which is the largest state by total area east of the Mississippi River. It is unique as the only state consisting of two peninsulas, making it one of the leading U.S. states for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionised publishing in the 1930s by introducing inexpensive paperbacks sold through Woolworths and other high street stores for sixpence, making high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction accessible to the mass market.
The film "Australia" (2008) was produced in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who contributed to making country music a worldwide phenomenon.
