Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and also a 2014 Egyptian film comedy directed by Amr Salama, based on his own experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. The film was initially considered too sensitive by the censorship board, leading Salama to adjust the script while trying to maintain the core concept of religious discrimination.
Derek Hough starred in Make Your Move, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired South Korean-American independent dance film in 2013.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga from her third extended play, The Fame Monster (2009). After an illegal demo leak, Gaga showcased the final product at Alexander McQueen's show at Paris Fashion Week in October 2009, followed by the release of the single's cover art. The song achieved worldwide success, topping charts in various markets and selling 12 million copies globally, becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time. Additionally, there is a 2011 independent drama film titled "Bad Romance" (Les Mauvais Romans).

DreamWorks Animation has released a total of 34 feature films, including franchises like Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, as well as other hits such as Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. Additionally, Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

Christopher Livingstone Eubanks, known as Chris Eubank, is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Christopher Livingstone "Chris" Eubank Jr., is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017. He previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush, born on July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist. She is known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. He is an Australian, British, American businessman and the younger son of media mogul Rupert Murdoch, serving as the chief executive officer of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc. Murdoch had full control as Chairman and CEO of global media holding company News Corporation, now the world's second-largest media conglomerate, and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after the conglomerate split on 28 June 2013.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest earning actress/models in Israel, behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with most of her income coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, often informally abbreviated to Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are typically detected by a radiographic examination, commonly referred to as an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield, known in Welsh as Maes glo De Cymru, is a large region in south Wales rich in coal deposits, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental football club competition organized by CONCACAF for the top football clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was originally known as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when first organized in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother when her eldest son, Edward, ascended the throne after George's death in 1936, but he abdicated later that year to marry Wallis Simpson. She then supported her second son, Albert, who became George VI until his death in 1952. She died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
Poseidon is a film that earned $181,674,817 at the worldwide box office with a budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first given during the 1996 ceremony. Omar Epps and Joe Morton hold the record for the most wins with three each.

Human trafficking involves the trade of humans, primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates that forced labor alone, a component of human trafficking, generates about $150 billion in annual profits as of 2014. Out of this, 14.2 million (68%) were exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) for sexual exploitation, and 2.2 million (10%) in state-imposed forced labor.
A sequel to Rio (2011 film), titled Rio 2, was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I, also known as François Étienne, was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, with his wife effectively holding the real powers of those positions. Another Francis I, the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigned from 1515 until his death. He was known as François au Grand Nez, the Grand Colas, and the Roi-Chevalier for his personal involvement in wars against his rival, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain Charles V. When this was unsuccessful, he formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with the Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian war of 1536-1538 was a conflict between King Francis I of France and Charles V.

Peking University, abbreviated PKU and known in Chinese as Běidà, is a major Chinese research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. It is the first modern national university established in China, founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking to replace the ancient Taixue or Guozijian. Initially, it served as the highest administration for education in China. The university is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his appearance, including his friendly mutton chops, his distinctive gravelly voice, and his distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming poses significant threats to humans, including risks to food security from decreasing crop yields and the potential abandonment of populated areas because of rising sea levels.
Australia is a 2008 Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.

Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore includes songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices like traditional food-making and craft-making. It also encompasses oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films, known for being both informative and entertaining. It also created training films and trained combat cameramen.

James Jones, an author, won the 1952 National Book Award for his first published novel, From Here to Eternity, which was adapted for the big screen and later made into a television series. Separately, James Jones, a basketball player, averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He has won three NBA championships, two with the Heat and one with the Cavaliers, and in 2017, he and teammate LeBron James reached the NBA Finals for the seventh consecutive year. Additionally, he finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-08 season and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is the process used for generating animated images, and Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, which became effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker, an English actor, is known for his portrayal of the fourth incarnation of the Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, a role with a longer tenure than any other actor. He also narrated the comedy series Little Britain and has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series in addition to performing acting roles.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

Hanford Site is home to a cleanup project, a commercial nuclear power plant called the Columbia Generating Station, and various centers for scientific research and development, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as a spokesperson for the executive branch of the U.S. government, particularly for the President, senior executives, and policies. This position is appointed by the president and does not require Senate advice and consent. Despite this, it remains a prominent non-Cabinet post due to the frequent media briefings that inform the public.

Kentucky, known as the Bluegrass State due to the bluegrass in its pastures from fertile soil, has the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky, which includes major cities like Louisville and Lexington. The state is also recognized for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also starred in The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, and formerly stylized as Ke $ ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, both an electronic version of Despacito produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA and an urban version produced by Sky were released.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). Initially broadcast via closed-circuit television, it eventually moved to pay-per-view, becoming the first NWA event to do so from 1987. The WWF scheduled Survivor Series on Thanksgiving night in 1987, demanding exclusivity from cable providers. In 2014, the WWE Network included previous Starrcades (1983-1986) transmitted via closed-circuit television, alongside other Starrcades in the pay-per-view section, rating the show as TV-MA due to the amount of violence in matches, especially the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum, T.A. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for the service and marks the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise concluded in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the National Football League (NFL) for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, as well as in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and also a 2014 Egyptian film comedy directed by Amr Salama, based on his experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.

A floppy disk, also called a floppy, diskette, or just disk, is a type of disk storage made of a thin and flexible magnetic storage medium. It is sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric that removes dust particles, and it is composed of a disk encased in a rectangular plastic carrier.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. From 1960 to 1996, it endured a bloody civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, which included genocidal massacres of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. Outside of medicine, they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after finishing its sixth season as cable's highest rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard is a fictional character and the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, played by Matthew Fox. Lost is an American television drama series that aired on the American Broadcasting Company from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons with a total of 121 episodes. The first season had an estimated average of 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew David McConaughey, an American actor born on November 4, 1969, has preferred dramatic roles since 2011, appearing in films like The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones. The film Mud (2012) stars him alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer is best known for his books, including Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine, his work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer, best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, the project's leader, died in 1941. Gutzon Borglum had created the sculpture's design and led the project from 1927 to 1941 with the help of his son, Lincoln Borglum, who then took over as leader of the construction project upon his father's death in March 1941.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents provided by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The TV series "The 100" follows a group of teens, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha, as they are among the first from the space habitat "The Ark" to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also centers on Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke's mother; Marcus Kane, a council member on the Ark; and Thelonious Jaha, the Ark's Chancellor and Wells' father.

The Concert for Bangladesh is recognized as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project, generating awareness and considerable funds, as well as providing valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent projects like Live Aid, despite being marred by financial problems due to the pioneering nature of the venture.
Mani Ratnam is cited by the media as one of India's influential filmmakers, credited with revolutionising the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas at the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. These debates, known as The Great Debates of 1858, were between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton attracted large crowds from neighboring states, as the issue of slavery was of monumental importance to citizens nationwide.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. It stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She started her professional writing career with the publication of "Interview with the Vampire" in 1976 while living in California, later writing sequels in the 1980s. Initially, her early works received mixed reactions, but she gained more popularity with critics and readers in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, and at the 2010 United States Census, it had a population of 77,344, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. At the beginning of the twentieth century, its population consisted mostly of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for The Canyons, a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader. The film is described as an original work and was critically derided.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates took place in seven towns in the state of Illinois.

Homer is the name given by ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are central works of ancient Greek literature. Additionally, The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Chris Cornell from Soundgarden and members of Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). Brad Wilk, known for his drumming in Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07), started his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, Wilk was playing in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consists of Zack de la Rocha (rapper/vocalist), Tim Commerford (bassist/backing vocalist), Tom Morello (guitarist), and Brad Wilk (drummer).

Janelle Monáe Robinson, an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model, is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, which is a concept album sequel to her first EP and was released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter 's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. About 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent overall come from Mississippi, with 23 percent being minorities, and international students representing 90 nations.
Flaked was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly, served as New York State Attorney General, was chosen as a U.S. senator from New York, and reached the apex of his career as vice president.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed for the Soviet space programme by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s, remaining in service today. It was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program, with 8 unmanned test flights followed by the first 19 manned launches. The Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Growing tensions over the band's direction led de la Rocha to quit, causing Rage Against the Machine to break up. De la Rocha pursued a low-key solo career, while the rest of the band formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, recording three albums before disbanding in 2007. The same year, Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion, performing together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in April 2007. Renegades is the band's fourth studio album, released on December 5, 2000 by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index consisting of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange and is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, as well as the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous Asian country. It is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the highest economic growth rates globally, and in 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. The country remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose acts of dramatic violence against the British in India and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement. He became a popular folk hero after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's "Dangal," which is a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I was King of Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from the union of the Scottish and English crowns on 24 March 1603 until his death. The kingdoms of Scotland and England were individual sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws, though both were ruled by James in personal union. He was a major advocate of a single parliament for England and Scotland and faced many difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack, a New Zealand stage and screen actress born on 26 December 1970, was one of the original core cast of the soap opera Shortland Street. She is also known for roles such as the Amazon Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her other works include the film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and portraying Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Recently, she notably played Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth for four years before leaving the show in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received generally mixed reviews from music critics but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies. It became Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States, selling 757,000 copies, and was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, which is also the group's last to feature him. He confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She has been a controversial figure, being lauded as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, even as arguments over Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his musical career, he has become a writer, penning weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has performed acting roles and also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative centre. It is also Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" was announced to have ended on April 26, 2012, with the third season being the final one, and its series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a sub-field of computational linguistics that focuses on developing methodologies and technologies to recognize and translate spoken language into text by computers. It draws from knowledge in linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces for tasks like voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft systems. Advances in the field are shown through academic papers and industry adoption of deep learning methods, with companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC using deep learning as the core technology in their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970. The event was originally founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans, including Alf, Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and was later called the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 Fist of Fury, which featured Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson carded a 67 to tie with overnight leader Van Zyl on 16 under par. McIlroy played a third straight five under-par 67, moving to 15 under par with Kiradech Aphibarnrat, including an eagle on the 12th. McIlroy, who had a tough start with three-putts, bounced back with a birdie and eagle. Despite a ligament injury in July, he returned to play in several events, aiming for a third Race to Dubai title in four years. He leads Danny Willett with three events remaining after the Turkish Open.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government must offer "concrete solutions" and have someone to speak for the royal family, pointing to Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist. He acknowledged that many young protesters have lost faith in main opposition parties but believed working with reformists within the royal family, including the Crown Prince, was the only way forward. The al-Wefaq leader recalled an agreement with the crown prince on a seven-point plan before GCC troops were brought in to crush dissent. He expressed hope that Senator John Kerry, as US secretary of state, would do more than his predecessor for Bahrain, calling for clearer and more direct US policy to pressure for human rights and democratic practices. Regarding the UK, he urged public statements to end violence and human rights abuses, criticizing private urging as ineffective. Additionally, he reiterated the call for peaceful demonstrations despite bans and demanded the release of opposition leaders and activists sentenced on evidence from torture, stressing their importance for the dialogue's success.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after an illness lasting several months, with a private funeral and a memorial service to be held later. He was a significant figure in the early-music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it for about 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was known for his influential recordings, such as the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. He worked with various orchestras, held positions as a keyboard player and musicologist, and was a tutor at Harvard University, among other roles. Colleagues and associates described him as having extraordinary generosity, being a great ambassador for historically informed music, and a very genial person who wanted the music to speak for itself.

In the year to the end of March, 57 homicide victims were recorded, marking a decrease from the previous 12 months and the lowest number for a single 12-month period since 1976. A sharp instrument, mostly knives, was the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. While most accused had an unknown status for alcohol and drugs, 31% were identified as under their influence. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need to continue efforts in education and enforcement to address violent crime, despite the encouraging decline in homicide cases. However, Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned against taking the statistics at face value, noting past revisions that showed an increase and highlighting a 45-year high in sexual crime and a 27% rise in violent crime, including attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth, known as the Cherries, lost 2-1 to Sunderland at the Black Cats, becoming the first team to do so in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling's goal was their first in three games, but they were stunned by goals from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Despite creating enough chances to win three games, Bournemouth couldn't find an equaliser, even when facing 10 men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal. Manager Howe expressed that the lack of scoring, despite prior success like scoring six goals against Hull, is difficult to take, emphasizing the need to move on from the result.

Mr Abbott stated that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," with Australia detaining migrants arriving by boat and taking them to offshore processing camps. The New York Times described this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and at odds with Australia's tradition of welcoming those fleeing persecution. Mr Abbott also claimed that the Islamic State (IS) is worse than the Nazis, which angered Australian Jewish groups. They responded by highlighting a fundamental difference between IS's actions and the Nazis' systematic genocide. Mr Abbott later said he stood by his comments but was not in the "business of ranking evil."

Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians, leading the US to suspend participation in bilateral talks with Russia. The US accused Moscow of failing to uphold commitments and allowing Syrian regime forces to target critical infrastructure, such as hospitals, and hinder humanitarian aid. Russia regretted the US move, accusing it of shifting blame for the truce's collapse and failing to improve Aleppo's humanitarian conditions. The situation in Aleppo has worsened, with heavy aerial bombardment, a main trauma hospital hit in an air strike, and hundreds of people, including children, dying after the truce lapsed. Despite the suspension, the two sides would continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations to avoid unnecessary clashes.

A report by think tank Policy Exchange, backed by Downing Street, suggests that selling high-value homes when they become vacant could raise £4.5bn a year, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. The report argues this could create the largest social house building programme since the 1970s, with the prime minister's spokesman stating that councils can already choose to do this. However, Labour opposes the idea, saying it would drive out hard-working families on low wages from whole neighbourhoods and that the government should use a bank bonus tax to fund affordable homes instead. The think tank defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the average in each region, accounting for 21.8% of the total stock. Critics, including the National Housing Federation and Labour MP Karen Buck, warn that such a move could push the least well-off out of expensive areas, creating segregated communities.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, a city experiencing an epidemic with 942 cases. An inquest will be opened and adjourned to allow further tests, as the examination couldn't establish if measles was the main cause of his death. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have needed hospital treatment. His mother mentioned he was recently treated for asthma at Swansea's Morriston Hospital, became unwell with a rash after discharge, and was found dead the morning after seeing an out-of-hours GP on 17 April. Public Health Wales confirmed a measles diagnosis but stated further tests were needed for the cause of death. The family is unsure how he got measles, as no close family member has it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

Vincent Hudson has been charged with a historical offence involving an attack on a boy under the age of 16, reported to have taken place in 2001. He is 54 years old and resides on Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, and is set to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Guiseley and Gateshead drew the match with a final score of 1-1. Guiseley went ahead early when a throw-in led to Jake Lawlor scoring into an empty net. Gateshead equalized in the second half after a slip by substitute Derek Asamoah allowed Wes York to curl a goal from the edge of the box. The game saw key moments like Liam Hogan blocking Jordan Preston's effort and Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted making a save from York's shot before the break. Substitutions and a yellow card to Gus Mafuta were also noted during the match.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, aims to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has faced delays due to a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the club will begin work, with the plan approved by Bristol City Council in November. The club plans to sign a section 106 agreement soon and wait for the judicial review period, intending to proceed with redevelopment in May if no judicial review occurs by March.

Cuadrilla has suspended drilling as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, and will examine data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding to resume. The BGS noted that the latest tremor, centered on Poulton-le-Fylde, shares a similar location and mechanism with an April quake. Shale gas drilling, or fracking, involves shattering hard shale rocks to release gas, and the process has been controversial, especially in the US, due to environmental concerns. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution, stating that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes. There have been two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began, with the latest event's epicenter within 2km of the Preese Hall site, and data indicating a similar location and mechanism to the April event.

Angus Carpenter, a Liverpool busker who has played in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud but cleared of two others. The 62-year-old was playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, and a court heard he gave the impression of collecting cash for the campaign. Carpenter defended that he was simply busking and that the banner was a tribute to victims, not an attempt to deceive. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, stated he had given permission for the banner but made it clear it should not be used to collect funds. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with Grant Ward's scuffed shot putting Town ahead, followed by Luke Varney scoring after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Tom Lawrence capped the scoring with a calm finish. Ipswich's win lifted them up four places to 14th, while Rangers slipped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy noted that Smithies cost them the second goal, and QPR boss Ian Holloway admitted the goal was a calamity, with his players needing to be mentally tougher.

Wells, 23, performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed that the club is moving in the right direction, finding it exciting, and noted the environment created by the coaches as one of elite performance, making the players want to be part of it.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win by beating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Churcher highlighted Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams for leading the team, noting the front row and front five made over 70 tackles. The Reds will face seven teams below them and league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight games. Churcher believes there's room for improvement, stating the performance against Chinnor wasn't complete but was emotionally dogged, and they need to build on it to avoid it being a waste of time.

Police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, also called Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun and was arrested at a Kolkata railway station. The incident, which caused outrage in India and led to street protests, marks the sixth arrest in the crime. Police have identified eight suspects, with two still untraced, and earlier accused arrested have named Nazrul as the person who raped the nun. The attack in Ranaghat town involved stealing money from a convent school, ransacking the building, and the nun being raped in the convent itself.

An interactive video, which may not work on older browsers, features Robert Opie from the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, discussing reasons for changes in what we buy. Factors like the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports have influenced items on sale and popular among UK consumers. The video also explores how ownership and ranking of some of the biggest UK brands are changing, with extra information available in a non-interactive format.

Two incidents occurred where women were scammed by individuals claiming to be from BT technical support. A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked on 15 September, and another woman in Stranraer lost money seven days later after a caller gained remote access to her computer. Police warn about the ease with which scammers access victims' computers and the substantial sums of money taken. They urge people to be cautious with cold calls seeking remote access and to never give out banking details or account numbers over the telephone, as banks and reputable businesses never ask for such information.

Duffy, 37, has joined a third-placed Championship side on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions, where he was replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler. As the Scotland assistant coach, he will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. The chairman expressed excitement about his role, noting that Duffy has done a remarkable job in difficult circumstances at Swinton and deserves credit for his efforts.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The rider had head injuries and was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand. She received treatment before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A decision was made at a UN conference in Geneva to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system, aiming to improve on the current system that relies on ground-based radars. Representatives from over 160 countries set aside a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes at the World Radiocommunication Conference, organized by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU). This will allow satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions, enabling real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world. The decision follows the disappearance of flight MH370, which exposed weaknesses in air navigation systems, as the current system leaves around 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at five and is now 18, was found living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is being held in Ohio after the FBI received a tip on 30 October, following issues the teenager had applying for college. The FBI worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm the boy's identity, and his mother has been notified. Bobby is also charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's licence in 2012 and is held at the Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had previously suspected the father around the time of the disappearance, as Mr. Hernandez said he was taking his son to pre-school in August 2002 but then fled.

Firefighters were at the Duncan Street site after a blaze on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire, with the firm being "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, as stated by the fire service. The site, run by Asset and Land Group, has until 7 August to appeal the decision. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months, and Geoff Harris, a GMFRS area manager, mentioned that concerns were raised to the EA in February about the fire's potential impact on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. This led to joint visits and the EA taking enforcement action, deciding to revoke the environmental permit. The revocation takes effect on 7 August, meaning the company will no longer be able to operate from that site, and it is still required to remove all the waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, introduced bills linked to the situation in Ukraine, particularly focusing on Crimea where separatist and pro-Russian feelings are strong. The bills propose that a referendum or a territory's leaders' plea could trigger provisions for a new "subject" of the Russian Federation, bypassing the need for a treaty with a neighboring state. Another bill aims to speed up Russian passport procedures for Ukrainians, allowing them to apply at Russian diplomatic missions before 1 August, become citizens after two months, without paying a state tax, requiring previous residence, sufficient funds, or giving up Ukrainian citizenship. The plan was announced in Sevastopol by A Just Russia leader Sergei Mironov, with several Russian MPs, including celebrities, visiting Crimea.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling, aiming for a fourth row on the grid and decent points. Despite their past greatness, including a dominant season in 1988 with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and recent periods of success with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines, the team has faced a slump, particularly since 2013 when they lost their way on chassis design. Now, they have the car but face issues with the Honda power-unit. The team has experienced cycles of triumph and decline, with past sponsor Marlboro bringing in Ron Dennis, who has held control since. Dennis believes success will return, asserting that McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony and become the next team to win the title. The team's current predicament is seen as a potential period of decline, but they believe in progress, with the car among the best this year and hope for Honda's engine improvement next year.

Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January after being shot in the head and chest, later dying in hospital. He had left Phoenix Gym at the market shortly before the shooting, with detectives believing those involved had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and the other 32, have been arrested and remain in police custody. Officers are searching for a silver VW Polo that left the scene at speed, traveling along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Authorities also mentioned that several people captured on CCTV near the meat market have yet to come forward, as they might have key information for the inquiries.

Traditional arguments about household responsibilities, like buying batteries for children's toys, can be a source of tension. To keep things more spiritual without giving up gadgets, there are five ways to enjoy Christmas online. Everyday Church Online offers virtual services with recorded sermons and a global congregation, including a Christmas theme inspired by Star Wars. Guardians of Ancora is a fantasy game aimed at children, featuring Bible-themed quests for Christmas. There are also charming nativity videos, like The Digital Story of Nativity, told through social media formats. Additionally, the Manga Messiah book, in app and e-book form, shares the nativity story in Manga style, targeting various audiences, including refugees. Groups are using platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect communities, with some suggesting Jesus would be on Twitter as a great communicator.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering around 320 hectares of replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting expert accounts about potential damage to habitats and plant life from building on the common land. Natural Resources Wales finds it "difficult to conclude" the replacement land is of equal value but isn't opposing the development overall. Developers claim a "net gain" in biodiversity through habitat enhancement, which the Gwent wildlife trust argues against. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers having the final say on the plans.

Chechen Muslim clerics, meeting on 3 April, stated that a report by Novaya Gazeta insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, with their resolution calling for retribution against the instigators, which the paper interprets as a call for reprisals against journalists. Novaya Gazeta had reported on over 100 detentions in Chechnya of people suspected of being homosexual, with at least three killed, and the Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's truth, citing torture of detainees. Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, and his spokesman claimed there are no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechen spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, confirmed "retribution" was part of the resolution. The report also mentioned influential Muslim clerics and Chechen TV presenters among the detainees. The LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution and accuses Russian authorities of ignoring abuses, threatening to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute.

Investing Solutions, a company set up by Samir Patel in 2002, has been receiving benefit payments by finding properties for single homeless men, often in collaboration with the charity Fresh Start Housing, which Patel also established in 2010. Neither the charity nor the company acts illegally, but a homeless group criticizes their relationship as a "new low." The letting agent makes money by placing multiple unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person, resulting in higher total benefit payouts than the rent passed to landlords. This venture is highly profitable, with records showing that nearly half of the money received over two years has been paid by Wandsworth Council. One tenant, Nigel McCann, described properties as unsuitable and highlighted the company's focus on profit over people. Fresh Start Housing claims independence and states that the majority of rents go to private sector landlords, while the Department for Communities and Local Government notes that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money.

Andrew Lawrence, a London 2012 Olympian, scored 14 points, and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 as Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters before being overtaken by their guests in the last 10 minutes of a well-contested game. GB now begins their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary. Prunty emphasized the importance of competing on every play and noted that the team lost some fire at times. The Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong with 18 points, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to lead 71-60 and held on to win despite GB's comeback. Prunty was pleased with Gordon's contribution, highlighting his good showing, especially in the third quarter.

The former five-weight world champion submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for a bout, with the NAC expecting a request from McGregor. Fights at 154 lbs require 10oz gloves, but Mayweather posted about wearing 8oz gloves, and the matter will be debated on 16 August. The NAC prioritizes the health and safety of fighters, and the decision to deviate from regulations will be determined by the chairman and commissioners. McGregor, making his boxing debut, has faced criticism from boxing personalities, but NAC executive director Bob Bennett studied information and found several reasons to approve the fight, including McGregor's performance against Nate Diaz and his physical advantages. McGregor's camp hired boxing referee Joe Cortez, who oversaw a sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi before leaving the camp.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post, are among the last journalists leaving Fleet Street as its London office closes. Once a vital place for public information, Fleet Street was the pinnacle of a journalist's career, with many national and provincial newspapers based there. The street, known for its bars and pubs, has seen a decline, with most newspapers moving away, adopting new printing technology. Mr. Smith and Mr. Sherriff reflect on the past, sharing memories of the bustling newsrooms and the shift to an environment now filled with sandwich bars. Following their redundancy, Mr. Smith is becoming a freelance journalist, while Mr. Sherriff is writing memoirs. The departure of these last two journalists marks the end of an infamous era in British history.

J.K. Rowling shared that her comments remind her of the world's size and the prevalence of decent people. She expressed that being a famous woman on Twitter isn't always fun and believes in standing up to bullies, especially after facing criticism for donating Â£1m to campaigns against Scottish independence and to the Labour party. Rowling revealed being called "a traitor" for her political views, blocking abusive Twitter users she thought were SNP supporters, and feeling no responsibility to protect any political party's image from such behavior. She also discussed having common ground politically with some SNP supporters and joked about bringing marshmallows after a suggestion to burn her books. The SNP now holds 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland, making it the third largest party in the UK.

Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action compared to better-off children committing the same crime, with poverty increasing the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. A study by University of Edinburgh researchers found that a history of police trouble is the strongest predictor of a young person not being in education, employment, or training by age 18, and that poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Household poverty exacerbates the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors are considered. The study also identified gender as a powerful predictor of violence, with boys three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts. Despite a recent fall in crime rates in Scotland, areas with the most chronic crime have not benefitted, with crime concentrated among poor people and in poor neighborhoods. The Scottish government claims Scotland is becoming safer, with crime at a 41-year low and initiatives in place to tackle poverty and inequalities.

Mr Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday and later pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and has been remanded in custody to appear again in court next week. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge. It will be alleged that Mr Walsh and two others entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr Haugh, encountered him and another man, and a fight ensued with weapons used. During the altercation, Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Police recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, including a knife handle and blade with blood on it. A judge noted evidence of tension in the area due to the killing and remanded Mr Walsh in custody until 14 August.

Phil Flanagan, an Fermanagh MLA, tweeted about Tom Elliott after he appeared on a BBC radio programme, suggesting Elliott might reveal how many people he harassed and shot as a UDR member. Elliott, who served in the UDR for 10 years and is now an MP, has a clear MoD record. The tweet was alerted to by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster, and Flanagan deleted it within an hour. An apology must be posted on Twitter, stating that the tweet was untrue and without foundation. Mr Justice Stevens has reserved judgement on compensation, and the insurance firm covering MLAs at Stormont has refused to cover Flanagan for any compensation and costs, which he is challenging in a separate court action. Elliott expressed being totally vindicated, noting that Flanagan admitted the comments were untrue, and he is disappointed it took so long to reach this stage.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff and dating back to 1874, has increased its sweater production to meet demand, boosted by better-than-expected sales of its Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January. The company, bought by managing director Benny Hartop last November, has also seen growth in its business of supplying garments under private labels. It sells in Europe to countries like Sweden, Finland, and Germany, as well as outside Europe to the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Production has risen to 9,500 sweaters weekly from about 7,500 last year. Mr. Hartop attributes the increase to a surge in orders from home and abroad for private label clients and their own brand, expressing confidence in continued success.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School when Brian Wright, 55, struck her while driving a VW Golf that failed to stop for a red light. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and heard a bump, then was in shock. He accepts hitting Blackburn, a much-loved lollipop lady, but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The incident occurred as Blackburn was on duty, escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. Wright expressed true sorrow for what he did to her and her family, and the court heard the sun could have been shining into his eyes. The trial continues.

NATO is conducting an exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," to train for anti-submarine warfare, focusing on the hunt for a German U-boat, U33, as a response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. This highlights a significant gap in Britain's defences, as it no longer has its own maritime patrol aircraft, leaving it reliant on NATO allies. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, and uses anti-submarine warfare helicopters and underwater drones to locate the invisible enemy. The lack of UK maritime patrol aircraft is seen as a key vulnerability, with concerns that a Russian submarine could track the nuclear deterrent. The purpose of the exercise is to ensure NATO readiness, but it also underscores that some nations, including Britain, cannot do it alone, and the government will need to address this in its forthcoming defence and security review.

United Nations officials suggest that genocide and ethnic cleansing could affect South Sudan, the world's youngest country, as violence has led to 340,000 people fleeing into Uganda, more than any other country this year. The crisis involves killing, rape, and targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, with reports of Dinka tribes not wanting Equatorians and Nuer. The civil war began as a dispute between President Salva Kiir and former Vice-President Riek Machar, with Equatorians targeted after rebel troops fled the capital. Uganda is coping with the influx, providing land and shelter for refugees, but is now struggling as the refugee population grows. The UNHCR's senior emergency coordinator calls for the international community to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the massacre of civilians.

McKenzie, 38, will face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. He became a professional boxer in 2013 after quitting football two years prior, with a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is part of a £330m investment for new NHS facilities in England, with the new hospital set to have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is described as cramped and outdated. The project's total cost is £33m, with the remaining balance to be paid by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Work has also started on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton. The aim is to build the new hospital on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with the goal of finishing it by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally injured with a gunshot wound to his chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre. He was either in or close to a black Mercedes car when the shooting occurred. Officers arrived at the scene at about 13:35 GMT, and the victim was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents mentioned the man was part of a family living nearby, with relatives gathering for a celebration when the attack happened. There have been several shootings in Sheffield recently, though previous incidents were in the north of the city, not close to Upperthorpe.
DID NOT RECIEIVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was emotional after veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil bid farewell to the parliament and again when Mr. Salmond said goodbye, as both are standing down ahead of the election on 5 May. Mr. Salmond, in his valedictory address, reiterated that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," emphasizing a journey towards the parliament assuming greater responsibility for Scotland's governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but insisted it didn't fulfill unionist pledges from the referendum campaign. Mr. McNeil, in his final speech, warned that Holyrood has things to learn from Westminster, especially regarding the committee system, stressing the need for accountability, scrutiny, and opposition. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also bowing out, joking about missing her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is calling on pensioners and their friends and families to share experiences of residential care to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. This is part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales, aiming to highlight both good and poor care impacts. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, with her team also speaking to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. However, the chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that the commissioner has not included a provider expert on the main advisory panel, missing an opportunity for partnership working and sector engagement.
DID NOT RECIEIVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon, with a man in his 80s also taken to hospital. Detectives are treating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, urging people not to approach him. The investigation is in its early stages, and officers are conducting additional patrols in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, highlighted risks in a speech, noting a weakening global economy and a delicate juncture. This follows weaker-than-expected Chinese trade figures, with exports plunging by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when releasing predictions in April, affecting businesses and industries that rely on China's growth story.

A council scrutiny meeting discussed problems with the new vessel, as the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July to allow feedback. Council leader Dave Stewart mentioned a review by auditors and described the ferry's start as frustrating and disappointing, with the chain ferry breaking down, running aground, and being suspended due to training issues. Cars have been damaged during on and off processes. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about losses from almost six months of trade, asking for compensation like for damaged cars. Transport councillor Ian Ward noted that compensation was up for discussion, stating it's a prototype with teething problems, including electrical issues now rectified. The council authorized ramp extensions to address vehicle scraping and resolved seamanship-related groundings.

A crash involving several vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene, and a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for the investigation.

Matching Models in London, an international temp agency, faced criticism for an advertisement seeking a personal assistant with a "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup," which the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women." Women's equality campaigners described the ads as "straight out of the 1970s," and an employment lawyer stated the use of phrases like "beautiful and attractive" could be discriminatory against older women. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practices, citing client importance and the need for the right people to represent companies. Another job advert for a "sexy female driver" was also deemed "clearly unlawful." The EHRC and others emphasized that such actions likely fall foul of equality legislation, urging the agency to act like a 21st Century business.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city, with the alleged gunman, Mahesh, identified as an office assistant at the school. Mahesh is said to have barged into the room of 18-year-old Gautami and shot her in the head with a pistol on Tuesday evening, also shooting another student, Sirisha, who suffered severe injuries but is believed to be out of danger. It is not clear what prompted the shooting, and Mahesh has been remanded until 12 April after being arrested on Wednesday following a manhunt. Incidents of gun crime at schools and colleges in India are very rare.

Glaad analyzed shows from June 2016 to May 2017, finding 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender characters increasing from seven to 16. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's Where We Are on TV study is based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already shown or with confirmed casting. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, expressed that it was heartening to see progress but emphasized that numbers were only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The BBC reported that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished, with about £10.25m missing and the loan under a police investigation for "alleged financial irregularities." Mr Mackintosh, who was criticized over the loan when he was leader, has denied any wrongdoing. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him, and he stated it is the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car driving away from a party in Balch Springs, Dallas, killing Jordan Edwards, 15. The incident occurred when police responded to reports of underage drinking, with officers inside a home when they heard what they believed to be gunshots. Oliver fired into the car full of teenagers as they left, and police had initially claimed the vehicle reversed aggressively towards him, but footage showed it driving forward away. He faces a murder charge and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official, related to other teenagers in the car, including two of the victim's brothers. The policeman was sacked for policy violations, and no trial date has been set. If convicted, Oliver would be the first police officer in Dallas County since 1973 to be convicted of murder. He is currently free on bail.

The president-elect has stated that Mrs. Trump and Barron will move to Washington after he finishes school, but no actual date has been set. This decision has drawn criticism on social media, with some calling it "appalling," while others support it as responsible parenting. Historically, only two First Ladies have not made the White House their home: Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. William Seale, a White House historian, notes that it is not unusual for children to stay back to finish school, as seen with President Grover Cleveland's wife and others. The role of the First Lady is primarily ceremonial, and Mrs. Trump has indicated Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not take on the full-time role predecessors like Mrs. Obama have. There is also mention of past examples, such as Chelsea Clinton and the Obamas, who managed family life in the White House while balancing duties.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October this year at a sheltered housing complex. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, has been tasked with scrutinizing the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is fully engaging with the investigation and awaits its findings. A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service in due course.

A yellow warning of wind was issued, with gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) expected locally, especially to the west of the mountains, and the unusual easterly direction could increase the winds' impact. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is likely, affecting counties such as Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts brought down a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route into the town, with Telford Road expected to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up work.

The Giants started with a short-handed opener by player-coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal to make it 2-1, with Andy Bohmback equalizing. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle, and James Desmarais made it 4-2 before Nottingham's David Ling got one back. The teams are set to meet again on Saturday night in the second match of their double-header, with Nottingham leading the league on 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers on 27 and Belfast on 25.

Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and did five pit stops, facing the challenge of overcoming a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races. Ferrari's Vettel came second despite colliding with Raikkonen, who fought back to fifth, passing Hamilton in the closing stages with the help of soft tyres. The race had an incident-packed opening, with collisions on the first lap leading to a safety car. Ricciardo made a strong start but suffered a puncture, allowing Rosberg to pass and lead. Hamilton, affected by damage from an incident with Nasr, had a difficult time and, after switching to medium tyres, couldn't recover as much ground as the Ferraris, facing an uphill battle to stop Rosberg from winning his first world title.

Thomas Hitzlsperger came out as the most prominent footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality, aiming to advance discussion of a topic ignored in German football. His announcement received praise from former team-mates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as support from figures in German football administration, including Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball, who called it a courageous step in the fight against homophobia. The move is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, where football has struggled with homophobia. Hitzlsperger's action has been welcomed by some, with hopes it will encourage others to break the taboo and lead to greater openness about sexuality in the sport.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, helping the Seagulls achieve promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at the end of the campaign, the midfielder is hoping to sign a new deal, expressing a desire to be part of the team next year as they aim to stay in the Premier League. Brighton's recent win over Wigan confirmed their promotion, and they are hoping to secure the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell previously made 19 appearances for Albion on loan from Stoke and has played in the Premier League with several clubs, believing he deserves another opportunity at the top level. He feels he has given a better impact than expected and is hoping to thrash out a new deal if one is on the table.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first with Nathan Delfouneso jinking past a player and delivering a chip into the area, where Jamille Matt turned the ball home. Colchester equalized from a corner as Kurtis Guthrie prodded in after a scramble. Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made key saves to deny Colchester, and Colchester failed to re-take the lead before half-time. Blackpool had chances to win, including Tom Aldred heading wide from a corner. The game ended with Colchester having 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was shown a straight red for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

A 29-year-old player made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. Reid, who has had spells with Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, could make his debut for the U's in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

PC Keith Palmer's murder outside the Houses of Parliament prompted a greater emphasis on the need for a permanent memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5m towards its construction at the National Memorial Arboretum, with the government committing £1m. The memorial, set to be completed by 2019, will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff, honoring their courage and sacrifice over the past 250 years. It will serve as a place for the nation to honor the police service and for families, friends, and colleagues to carry out personal acts of remembrance.

United remain 15 points clear at the top with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. Ferguson emphasized focusing on what is in front rather than what is left behind, noting the players' record of 25 wins out of the first 30 matches. The team has 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games and aims to better Chelsea's record 95-point haul in 2005. Ferguson will make changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries suffered at Sunderland, including goalkeeper David De Gea. He mentioned the win was owed to determined defending and courage, despite a difficult second half from Sunderland.

Mr Schmidt stated that Google paid what was "legally required" in taxes, including Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, and emphasized that it was up to the government to change tax laws if it wanted companies to pay more. He viewed taxes as not optional and said that if the British system changed tax laws, they would comply. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge suggested a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, and European Union leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange. Google, routing most UK sales through Ireland, is criticized for minimizing UK tax payments. The Google chairman has argued for corporate taxes to be levied where economic activity and risks occur, rather than where products are consumed, and called for a debate on international tax reform, hoping to move the debate forward with a clearer, simpler system.

NHS Improvement wants more progress in reducing the NHS agency bill, which last year was £3.6bn, aiming to bring it down by £1bn by the end of this financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m, limiting payments for staff, excluding senior managers, to no more than 55% above normal shift rates. While the progress is described as "promising," the NHS is still short, with trusts 10% down on their target. The agency bill is falling, but it's unclear if spending on other parts of the pay bill has risen. The figures don't cover NHS bank staff or money spent on overtime for employed staff. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust. Examples show hospitals being quoted rates exceeding the cap, with one trust quoted £130 an hour for a surgeon when the cap is £76. NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey emphasized the need for more action, stating the NHS doesn't have the money to keep paying for expensive agency staff.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger, now stands as a monument to Ireland's economic crash. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien of a family-owned men's clothing shop, believe bad times are slowly changing, with business showing improvement through diversification into areas like childrenswear and dress-hire. Fianna Fáil criticizes the Fine Gael-Labour coalition for not adequately addressing the midlands, arguing that funds should be spent on broadband instead of water meters and that the IDA hasn't brought potential clients to Longford in over four years. The government, however, points to the Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, which could employ 1,000 people, as a positive move, though it still needs planning permission. Traders feel more could be done to support local business, such as addressing parking charges, indicating that while an economic recovery is beginning, more efforts are needed.

The competition concludes on 29 May in the same stadium, featuring eight teams that face each other twice, with the top four sides qualifying for the play-offs. You can track all scores, fixtures, and results with BBC Sport. Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan for Sunrisers Hyderabad, Jos Buttler with Mumbai Indians, Sam Billings for Delhi Daredevils, and Kevin Pietersen for Rising Pune Supergiants. Fixtures and results are provided, including the final on Sunday, 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs found that the number of plastic carrier bags had increased by 200 million since 2013, causing environmental issues as many can't be recycled and end up in rubbish dumps and rivers. To address this, people in England will have to pay 5p for plastic bags from October, aiming to encourage reuse. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where charges are already in place, have seen a decrease in bag usage. Campaigners hope this charge in England will reduce the amount of bags being thrown away, helping the environment.

A part of a school roof was ripped off at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, Gwynedd, as hundreds of homes in Wales faced power cuts, train delays, and speed and lane restrictions on major bridges. This occurred following a yellow 'be aware' wind warning across Wales, which was in effect until midnight on Friday.
