The highest gusts were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey, leading to Irish Ferries cancelling six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin and Arriva Trains Wales warning of speed restrictions and possible delays. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to expected high winds. Winds eased into Friday evening, with restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge lifted. A blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend caused at least one festive event, Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip, to be postponed to Tuesday, 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about a new project, wanting to put a different spin on it, and will reunite with Creed director Ryan Coogler. He is also looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o, an Oscar winner for 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, who is playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four, and Nyong'o portrayed Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther is set for release in February 2018.

A theatre, founded in 1875 and part of Alexandra Palace, is hoped to be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music, with plans to reopen in 2018 if funds are raised successfully. The BBC studios at the eastern end will also be repaired and refurbished. This theatre and studios form part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination, including the glazed east court becoming a public and exhibition space. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the final £1m by summer 2017. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m.

A former Manchester City player, now 30, has won 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, playing just three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps after his first appearance in 2004, and scored his first and only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. He expressed that the decision reached is about common sense and wished Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters success in the future.

Marcy Smith was woken up by her son David to find their house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, engulfed in flames. The family escaped, but their house is destroyed, and their dog and cats did not survive. David, who was on FaceTime to his father, was the only one awake and saw the flames, getting them up just in time as the fire spread quickly. Mrs. Smith said the fire was started by burning rubbish in the wood stove, something she had done many times before, and the fire alarm did not go off. The community has supported them by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for her son. She expressed pride in David, stating he was the reason they survived.

An energy drinks giant was reported to be considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club, West Ham, which Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010 for £105m, now owning over 85% of the club. West Ham has been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium in August. Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts but intends for ownership to pass on to their children.

Jillian Bell commented that the event was not the Oscars, highlighting fan-voted awards like best kiss and best shirtless performance, with Efron winning the latter again. The ceremony served as an unofficial promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the night's big winner, taking best movie, while Shailene Woodley received best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss for a scene with Ansel Elgort. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep for best villain in Into the Woods. Kevin Hart brought his kids on stage to accept the comedic genius award, and Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award with his fellow Avengers stars. Clips from upcoming releases like Pitch Perfect sequel, Trainwreck, and Ultron were shown.

Smith, a 21-year-old with a Scotland Under-21 cap, was loaned to United by the Dons in July and has scored five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren's boss Jack Ross described Smith as a brilliant acquisition, a really good player, and a mature boy who provides an option in the attacking area. Ross mentioned he didn't think they'd be able to get Smith because he was at Dundee United.

Northumberland County Council stated that the weather is now warm enough for Jetpatcher machines to address holes, aiming to fill in 145 potholes each day over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will work on repairing drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clearing debris from gutters.

In December, on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland, six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while working on pipe equipment during shutdown activities. They were told there was a problem two-thirds into the trip, with a health and safety manager indicating a reading had been taken the night before, leading to work being stopped. The workers had been working without proper PPE, as it was assumed the area was clear. EnQuest stated the exposure was less than 1% of a reportable level and advised the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) at the time, taking additional precautionary steps afterward. Wood Group downmanned employees for medical assessments and supported a joint investigation, emphasizing employee health and safety. Mr. Innes expressed concerns about EnQuest's duty of care, with the workers now facing cancer fears and undergoing blood tests. The HSE noted the incident was not reportable under the RIDDOR system, and no separate investigation was carried out.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The company's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this bronze, which is thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. After discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the decision was made to return the sculpture following the ASI's official request. The museum acknowledged the manager's confession to dealing in looted items and criminal possession of stolen objects, even though there is no conclusive proof of the sculpture's origin. ACM plans to take legal action for compensation due to the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, felt as far as Milan and Florence, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The tremor, occurring in Garfagnana, was accompanied by several aftershocks, causing phone lines to go down and power supplies to be cut. Schools in the immediate vicinity were evacuated as a precaution. This follows previous earthquakes in the area, including a deadly magnitude-6 quake last May. Italy, prone to earthquakes, is still recovering from the L'Aquila quake in 2009, where almost 300 people died. Six scientists and an ex-official were convicted for giving falsely reassuring statements before that event, leading many to remain in their homes and perish.

Austin Grant from Sheffield, initially doubtful about South Yorkshire's climate, is now happy after seeing results, with the fruit still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat. The 62-year-old grandfather expressed his joy by jumping for it.

Rockstar has delayed the game's release until 24 March, originally set for 27 January, stating it needs extra weeks of testing and polish to ensure quality. They emphasized that moving the release date is a decision made only in the best interests of the game and fans, assuring the extra weeks will be worth it. Before the PC release, online heists are coming to consoles, and screenshots from the PC version show "even greater levels of detail," with Los Santos and Blaine County visible in 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. Minimum specifications for running GTA V have also been published.

A 76-year-old artist, previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, won the Â£25,000 prize for his painting Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The judge, Ansel Krut, described the work as "quite extraordinary" and likened it to a tone poem, noting its technical subtlety and minimal language that evoke great sympathy. Squint (19) depicts a leper squint, holes in medieval churches allowing undesirables to view services. The artist mentioned it is part of a series, with some paintings being much bigger, and entered it due to its relatively small size and being something he was working with. The prize money will be used for stretches, canvas, and particularly good quality paints. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by four masked assailants, with no casualties reported. Firefighters extinguished the blaze, and police cordoned off the area. Both papers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously early on Thursday, with windows shattered by gunfire and numerous spent bullet casings found at both scenes. Police are now hunting the assailants, and no group has claimed responsibility.

A 24-year-old, previously under contract with the Stags and on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, has been brought in on a free transfer by Marcus Bignot's side. He will officially join on 1 January, becoming Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger, with a club contract running to the summer, has been linked to a job but focuses on his current role. Southgate, who succeeded Sam Allardyce in September, has overseen England's matches, including a win against Malta and a draw with Slovenia. Wenger comments on Southgate, noting his experience and the need to show competency, as Southgate has a World Cup qualifier and a friendly to persuade the Football Association for a permanent position. Wenger also mentions that Hector Bellerin, a 21-year-old defender, will be offered a new contract by the club despite speculation about moves to Barcelona and Manchester City. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay, where the RMT union claimed some workers on freight boats were paid less than Â£4 an hour. The change will bring contracted out services back to operator Serco Northlink from next month, with the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay previously operated by Seatruck. Seatruck argued the national minimum wage did not apply to the crew, many non-UK residents, while Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap, which was declined. The new arrangements, subject to financial and regulatory details, aim to ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage, ending the long-running issue around the freight vessels serving the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha, and had pleaded guilty to common assault in relation to the fight. Both Mr. Mitchell and his mother admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events, initially telling police that Mr. Dickie had pushed Mrs. Mitchell and she had pushed him back. Mr. Mitchell later stated he tried to push the couple apart, causing what he described as a "tragic accident." They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton died in London at 66 after a brief aggressive battle with cancer, remembered for his work as a songwriter, including hits like Off The Wall and Baby Be Mine for Michael Jackson and Boogie Nights for his band Heatwave. He was nicknamed The Invisible Man due to his low profile and influenced by his father's use of a transistor radio. Temperton's songs contributed to Jackson's breakthrough album Off The Wall and the best-selling album Thriller, with tracks like the title track, Baby Be Mine, and The Lady in My Life. His work also earned a Grammy Award and Oscar nominations. Tributes from figures like Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson highlighted his impact, with Warner/Chappell's Jon Platt noting his family's devastation and request for privacy.

A team including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott has discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in the western Brazilian Amazon. These include over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" revealed by modern deforestation. The function of these sites is still little understood, as they are unlikely to be villages or for defensive reasons, with the possibility of being used as ritual gathering places. Dr Loader analyzed soil samples, finding that the geoglyphs were constructed among taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy, unlike the Maya pyramids. The research challenges the assumption that Amazonian forests were pristine before Europeans arrived, indicating that people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. There is evidence suggesting that the biodiversity in some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a legacy of these ancient agroforestry practices.

The Australian, Kyrgios, beat world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round. Ranked a career-high 12th, Kyrgios recently won the Japan Open and is nearing the top 10. He mentioned feeling bored and tired, attributing it to his success in Japan and the travel involved at the Qi Zhong Stadium, an hour from Shanghai city center. Kyrgios also noted poor sleep and a tough ride to the courts. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, he was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst, calling the tournament a "circus."

Scientists and charities argue that the human papilloma virus (HPV) jab can protect against head and neck cancers, with Welsh groups like Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team delivering a letter to the Welsh government to call for rolling out the vaccination. They note an increase in head and neck cancer cases, affecting younger people, mostly men, and non-smokers. Dr. Mererid Evans and Jon Antoniazzi emphasize the need for Wales to take a progressive step by vaccinating boys, as HPV causes 5% of the global cancer burden. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering any changes to the HPV vaccination programme, which has already vaccinated 85% of girls in Wales since a 2008 school rollout.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, briefly attended a school prom held in his honor before feeling unwell. His mother, Allison, broke the news of his death on his Facebook page. Jak had been documenting his life and treatment on social media through a page called Jak's Journey, which attracted more than 28,000 Likes. His story of fighting cancer and his positive attitude touched many. On 23 January, doctors informed Jak and his family that his cancer had spread, and they decided not to pursue further treatment. Jak expressed his determination to fight the pain and get as many days as possible. His family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and more money is expected to be raised for charity at a special football match.

In a drab game with few chances, Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0, with Mohamed Salah setting up El Said to score in the 89th minute. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier, and the win means Egypt will play Ghana for top spot in Group D, while Uganda is out of their first tournament since 1978.

Lancashire County Council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a potential railway station, following a comparative study by Network Rail. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans for Skelmersdale to have two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis highlighted the preferred location's size for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The council will now begin acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the northwest of England without its own railway station.
Plants were discovered during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, found in an elaborate grow house, leading to the arrest of a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement late on Sunday in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent an emergency operation and was flown to a specialist clinic. The woman's ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, later handed himself in to authorities. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police have secured the area, calling for witnesses to come forward.

Women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but they are less likely to get one, according to research by the Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, which looked at 4,600 workers. The study found no support for the "reticent female" theory, where women avoid asking for more money, and eliminated part-time worker impacts by comparing like-for-like male and female workers. When men asked, they were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise. The research also concluded no evidence that women were reluctant to ask due to being more wary of upsetting their boss or deviating from a female stereotype. The study, based on the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, considered factors like employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications. Andrew Oswald, a professor, noted that the findings suggest some element of pure discrimination against women and that young women today are negotiating pay and conditions more successfully than older females, potentially indicating a change in negotiating behavior.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a suitable new burial site for many years, using money for ground investigations of possible sites without success. Two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, still have space but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council has not given up and is still exploring options, as all identified council-owned sites have been discounted due to size, ground conditions, a high water table, or restrictive covenants. Once the remaining cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival can use an app to trigger online information from items like signs and posters, offering videos and band interviews viewable on phones and tablets. The festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan. This augmented reality experience is an extra feature to enhance enjoyment, allowing people worldwide to interact with the festival, capture its atmosphere, and access information, interviews, and ticket purchases at any time.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He was treated by veterinary staff before being pronounced dead, with the British Horseracing Authority confirming the cause as a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, noted that such episodes are rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, including overheating and wobbling on his feet, but had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms on Saturday. Questions have been raised about whether his tendency to overheat was linked to his death, but the report concludes he was the victim of a rare haemorrhage.

A 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in the autumn of 2004, and it was reported that Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, raped the teenager while two others were asleep. The victim recalled shouting and swearing at Ayrton to stop the attack, as her friends had not woken up. Ayrton, now 34 and having changed her name in 2012, denied the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely at a male prison, stating there were substantial grounds to believe she would be a risk to herself and of failing to attend if released on bail. During the trial, Ayrton spoke about her sexuality, saying she had not made any physical changes or enhancements to her body or taken any medication. The court also heard that in 2014, Ayrton told a care home worker about the attack.

The Serbs lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio with a score of 6-4 6-4. This loss followed Djokovic being knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. World number one Djokovic had previously suffered a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July against American Sam Querrey. He later came back to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US are set to participate in Saturday's event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms. They will use only chainsaws to carve logs into shapes of animals and people, as other carving tools are banned. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, is returning to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb has not played since a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September but says he is close to a return, aiming to get fit before the Six Nations in February. He is currently in a pre-season stage and considering a potential return at the beginning of February, possibly with a few weeks shaved off the timeline. Wales will start their Six Nations campaign away to Ireland on Sunday, 7 February. Webb, who has been capped 16 times by Wales, has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay at his home region where he made his debut in 2007.

US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks five miles east of Sumas, Washington, interrupting an attempt to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One man, identified as Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody, while the other, Nathan Hall, fired a weapon at agents and fled. Hall was later arrested by the Abbotsford Police Department. Investigators also arrested Kali Henifin, a Bellingham, Washington woman, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who were accused of planning to pick up the men and drive the drugs to San Francisco. The three face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is a well-known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

Childline, the NSPCC's service, reported counselling over 4,500 children in the past year, a significant increase from about 2,400 in 2011-12, highlighting a rise in online abuse. Some children as young as seven shared experiences of being tormented, abused, and scared to attend school, with online trolls causing misery and humiliation. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized the need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, as bullying, especially cyber-bullying, does not stop on its own and can follow children home, becoming a persecution they cannot escape. The report's release coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, where the Anti Bullying Alliance is working with parents, schools, and organizations to combat the issue. A young person described being told to kill themselves by online peers, expressing that it upsets them and their parents do not fully understand the impact.

The US chose not to veto a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who claimed the White House had helped draft the resolution. Israel rejected the resolution, particularly angered by the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem. In response, Netanyahu summoned ambassadors and took other diplomatic actions. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing new homes in settlements at the request of the prime minister's office to avoid straining relations with Washington before US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to outline his vision for ending the conflict and address critiques of the Obama administration by Israel. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as paving the way for an upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

In a BBC interview, a tribute was paid to the Queen on the eve of her 90th birthday, highlighting her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. Events to mark her birthday included a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, opening a new bandstand, and the release of stamps featuring the Royal Family. Political leaders like David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn expressed anticipation for wishing the Queen a happy birthday. Prince William discussed his commitment to royal duty, acknowledging criticisms but emphasizing the importance of finding his own way and taking responsibilities seriously when the time comes. The Queen's actual birthday on Thursday involved walking around Windsor and unveiling a plaque, with an evening beacon lighting. Additionally, the US President and First Lady will join her for lunch at Windsor Castle.

West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory over Cheltenham Town, with two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew giving them control before half-time. Cheltenham had chances, including Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but could not find the net. The hosts also saw moments like Pell's low volley and a near miss by substitute Dan Holman. West Ham could have extended their lead, but Cheltenham's captain Kyle Storer cleared a header off the line, and keeper Jonathan Flatt stopped Sakho from turning in Ayew's cross. The match ended with Cheltenham's exit, ending League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to see the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, resulting in a £1,000 fine and a two-year driving ban in the UK. The victim's family, as stated by prosecutor Sarah Marsh, saw no value in sending Werner to jail, accepting it was a momentary lapse. Craig Hutchinson, defending, mentioned Werner was remorseful and had no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, returned to the UK after being one of the most public British fighters in Syria, where he was involved with the group Rayat al Tawheed affiliated to Islamic State. He faced a possible life imprisonment for his role in Syria's battlefields, having posted videos and images of his personal jihad, including appeals for donations and propaganda. Khawaja faked his own death with an online obituary and tried to sneak back into Britain, but police were waiting. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, admitted assisting an offender. Khawaja is considered a dangerous man who chose the path of terrorism, trained in Syria, and concealed his entry. He has admitted four offences, while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Jackson, 22, who scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth, is Barnsley's third signing for next season. He turned down a contract offer from Wrexham. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom noted that Jackson has pace to burn, likes to get at defenders, and will fit in nicely to the way they play.

Bottles have been arriving at Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves, with National Trust volunteers clearing them due to the risk they pose to wildlife. The bottles are sealed, but some have reportedly leaked. It is believed a container holding these bottles went overboard from a ship during stormy weather, possibly near Land's End in May. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes that while the MV Blue Ocean lost a container with 'Vanish' bottles, there is no current evidence linking the washed-up bottles to this container. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is highly concerned about the impact on marine life, and the National Trust is worried about detergent entering the marine environment. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00, resulting in several people receiving minor injuries. The road was closed, with diversions set via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson noted that Dorian was a bit of a forgotten man last year but made an excellent contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite follows David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in signing new contracts with Bolton after their promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything," with Labour's leader in the Lords, Baroness Smith, countering that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope." The two parties had previously cooperated to defeat the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but that collaboration ended when MPs rejected those amendments, with Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems as engaging in "fairly obvious grandstanding" for campaign leaflets, while the Lib Dems' Europe spokesperson, Baroness Ludford, accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and aligning with Conservatives for a hard Brexit. Despite past alliances on issues like higher education and housing, there are now residual tensions, with Labour not envisioning much demand for a "progressive consensus summer drinks" gathering, though the Liberal Democrats remain open to working with peers on agreed-upon issues.

Defence is low on political parties' priority lists, with opinion polls showing it barely in the top 10 of electorate concerns, behind the economy, the NHS, and immigration. UK military interventions may have caused public combat fatigue, and politicians are on the defensive about defence. The UK has been cutting armed forces, with the Army size reduced and the Royal Navy and RAF having limited warships and jet squadrons. Capability gaps exist, like no Maritime Patrol Aircraft, and the UK has fallen to sixth in global defence spending. A commitment to spend 2% of GDP on defence is absent, with only UKIP and the Democratic Unionist Party pledging to meet that goal. Future governments are likely to face more cuts, especially as parties do not plan to protect defence spending like the NHS. The Conservatives have limited their options by promising to replace Trident and increase the defence equipment budget, but this could hinder finding significant savings. There is no political consensus on the nuclear deterrent, with Labour, the Liberal Democrats, SNP, and Greens having different stances. The Royal Navy's new aircraft carriers may struggle with crewing and equipment, risking a "hollow force" with insufficient people despite advanced equipment.

Barcelona insists they have not committed any offence regarding the signing of Neymar, making a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to address possible interpretations of tax responsibility from the player's signing. The club paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee, and the total cost, including various fees, is estimated at £106.8m. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer, but the board denies any tax-related crime, remaining convinced the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. It is yet to be confirmed whether the case will be dropped after the payment.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old from Nottingham, was a passenger in a van that collided with a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Mr. Luciw's family and colleague Andy Harrington, who was driving the van and sustained serious injuries, called for retired drivers to undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations, arguing that older drivers' reactions slow down and people should not be on the road if they shouldn't be. They emphasized that if the driver hadn't been on the road, Michael would still be with his daughter. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licences, without a medical or driving test. The DVLA stated it has no plans to restrict licensing based on age, noting that evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK highlighted the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely for as long as possible.

Many women have questioned the safety of implants used to treat incontinence after suffering debilitating side effects, leading to concerns about the review process. Two patients on the original review group quit in protest at a watered-down report, and now independent expert Alison Britton will examine the final report's process and conclusions. The report concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse, recommending a range of treatments and informed choices, with mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the recommendations will continue to be implemented. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report, acknowledging it was "almost mission impossible" from the start. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, who had suffered complications, also resigned, feeling dismayed and disgusted, with a consultant quitting over concerns about the final draft. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, and more than 400 are currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Muir, 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan had raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria for a record-breaking attempt, noting it was a mixed 3K race where Muir was the only one finishing the 5K. Despite these concerns, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official, with the time undergoing ratification. McColgan praised Muir's ability, saying she has what it takes to win world medals and that there's more in her tank, expecting her to run around 14.30 in the 5K. She also mentioned that Muir's race was similar to her own record-breaking one, and it was a bonus that her record was beaten by a fellow Scot.

Jung won aboard Sam, a late replacement due to Fischertakinou's infection. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze, with GB's William Fox-Pitt finishing 12th. Fox-Pitt, who was in an induced coma after a fall just 10 months prior, had a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase but had already seen his medal bid ruined by a disappointing cross-country phase, dropping from leading after dressage to 21st after incurring time penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Murray, a 30-year-old Briton, won a tense match against Fognini after two hours and 39 minutes, with the victory coming in four sets (6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5). Despite Fognini having five set points to force a fifth set, Murray secured five consecutive games to advance to the last 16 for the 11th time. He will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round. The match was affected by fading light, with Murray expressing that it was an up and down game, and he was pleased to finish in four sets without needing the roof to be brought on.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, with police finding people still at the bar. Till receipts showed alcohol served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas, both from the same address, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. A defence solicitor noted that licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to, and the premises had not been run properly, operating well into the morning. The judge described Ms. O'Neill, the license holder, as having an "appalling record" and expressed concern about lacking power to impose a custodial sentence. Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, during a speech launching the party's manifesto, emphasized that "domination doesn't work, partnership does," shifting the election focus to how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled. He addressed Danny Kennedy's distancing from his remarks, finding it reaffirming, and denied any regrets, insisting on not withdrawing his words. Nesbitt expressed a preference for going into Stormont Castle with the SDLP over Sinn Féin, highlighting confidence in his position and the candidates' varying vote transfer stances. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' includes actions for tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off from Brexit. It also calls for cleaning up Stormont, framing the election as a referendum on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption, while Nesbitt must hope this message resonates more than the controversy over his SDLP remarks.

A motion will go before the assembly for approval, aiming to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales regarding automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. Dubbed 'Turing's Law', the provisions would allow posthumous pardons and enable living gay and bisexual men to apply for a pardon. The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion for pardoning these convictions, with the goal of ensuring equal treatment and righting past wrongs as soon as possible.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon in four minutes, 19.12 seconds, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60 and moving her to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. This achievement marks Muir as the new record holder for the Scottish 1500m and mile. She expressed her pleasure with the record and excitement about getting close to Kipyegon. Muir, who fits her training around veterinary studies, aims to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham. She started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm.
Some pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland, which are ranked as the "most excellent" for water quality, are provided.

A Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Mr. Litvinenko, suggesting the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot. UK officials believe the two poisoned Mr. Litvinenko in London in 2006, with him drinking tea containing a fatal dose of radioactive polonium-210, leading to his death in hospital. The use of polonium indicates Russian state participation, though Horwell emphasized this does not mean President Vladimir Putin was involved. Litvinenko's defection to the UK and personal attacks on Putin could have been seen as treachery. Horwell also mentioned the risk to the public from polonium radiation is unknown and that Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death. The suspects left a "trail of polonium" and have no credible answer to the evidence against them, with extradition attempts failing and them remaining in Russia.

Smith, 26, will captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch and has been appointed as the ongoing leader, having already led the one-day side. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite a history of disciplinary problems, with selectors noting his maturity and development. This follows Clarke's decision to retire after his side's defeat in the Ashes. Smith had previously captained the team in Tests against India when Clarke was recovering from injuries. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval, starting on 20 August.

Mr. Farron, who became leader by beating Norman Lamb, refused to answer if he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating his firm belief that we are all sinners. He expressed being passionate about LGBT-plus rights, with defending equal marriage at the top of his agenda and wanting to extend marital rights to transgender people. When asked why he voted against the Equality Bill in 2007, he clarified his support for equality and mentioned the Lib Dems tabled an amendment due to concerns about individual liberties. He did not directly address those concerns but affirmed his favor for equal access under law for all people regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Now, Accord Healthcare plans to use the plant for pharmaceutical production, hoping to fill many jobs with ex-Sanofi staff. A spokesman expressed confidence that the investment would have an "extremely positive" impact on the area. Councillor Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council, welcomed the announcement, stating it strengthens the region's reputation as a home for the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis is leaving on Friday at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are going under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, views these departures as indicative of the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects further departures in the coming months. Mr. Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance, has also been acting as deputy chief executive. Mr. Monaghan is head of the chief executive's office, and Mr. Sutherland is head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked Sardar Daud hospital, detonating explosives at the gate and opening fire on staff and patients. Commandos killed all four attackers after several hours of fighting, with the so-called Islamic State (IS) claiming the attack and the Taliban denying involvement. More than 50 people were wounded, and President Ashraf Ghani condemned the assault, highlighting the hospital's role as an immune site. This marks a change in IS's approach in Afghanistan, as they now engage directly with security forces in the capital, using a method more associated with the Taliban. The attack suggests IS has the resources and military training to expand, potentially leading to more such assaults. IS has previously targeted civilian gatherings and the Supreme Court, and the government claims to have rooted out militants from some bases but not from mountainous areas they control.

An English rider crashed at this year's TT, and the Fireblade bike has had mechanical issues. Martin told MCN he was quitting road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing or road racing, just has no plans for more road racing on Hondas this year. He didn't race at the North West 200 after his team-mate crashed in practice and won't compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a disaster, noting they were going to struggle and that he ended up being a test rider. After more testing at Cadwell, he told the team the bike wouldn't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. He mentioned there's no unfinished business and wants to race classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but held on to Rivers State and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP failing to secure a national spread of votes. The APC did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari regarding oil revenue and militant disruptions. Some elections were marred by violence, especially in Rivers and other southern states, though overall, the elections were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP, which was in power for 16 years, faces a need for introspection and rebuilding after allegations of corruption and failure to address the Islamist-led insurgency.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, has accused the agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to haze caused by slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia. Both companies reject these allegations, with Olam stating it has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy and Temasek asserting it does not direct business operations of portfolio companies. The report also highlights concerns in Gabon, where Olam is accused of bulldozing rainforests for palm oil plantations, to which Olam responds by emphasizing responsible and transparent private-public partnerships. The palm oil industry is described as having a troubled track record, often accused of environmentally unfriendly practices, with green groups and executives at odds over these issues.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters following a new law that permits dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they are outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is uncertain to play due to a knee issue, having only come on from the bench in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent might return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield, while midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring a late leveller against the Terriers from the bench.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube, stating it was no longer necessary as Google, which owns YouTube, had launched a Pakistan-specific version. Many young Pakistanis welcomed this change, but some activists want more transparency about the deal with Google. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed that all internet service providers were directed to open access to YouTube. The government claims Google has provided a process for the PTA to request blocking of offending material, with YouTube agreeing to restrict such content for users in Pakistan. However, a YouTube spokeswoman noted that government requests for content removal won't automatically be granted, emphasizing community guidelines and a thorough review for local restrictions. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 after the controversial film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded, sparking protests and deaths in Pakistan.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, like presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. LFA boss Musa Bility is threatening to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which bars members with conflicts of interest. Scala previously stepped aside in 2015 when sharing nationality with candidate Sepp Blatter, but now argues there is no conflict as there are five candidates with no incumbent President. Bility wants to know why the same process hasn't been followed for the upcoming 26 February election, emphasizing the importance of fairness and integrity. If Scala doesn't step down, the Liberian FA may challenge the decision. The election will see Prince Ali, Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale competing to replace Blatter, voted on by Fifa's 209 members in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been conducted at the company, which makes buckets for diggers, with Det Ch Insp Paul Durham indicating significant progress in inquiries and obtaining witness statements. Evidence suggests a flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and some sort of ignition leading to a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with its inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia faced possible expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after complaining to Caf about an incident during this year's Nations Cup, but a rapprochement was achieved following a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Morocco was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban and reduced a fine. The Tunisians had a row with Caf over a contentious penalty in a quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a furious letter and a demand for an apology to avoid disqualification. The Tunisia Football Federation insists it never accused Caf or the referee of corruption, stating the referee was badly chosen. Both nations are now preparing for the Nations Cup, with Tunisia facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, and Morocco set to play Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

A mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute of the game at Etihad Stadium, where Chelsea won 3-1. Manchester City had forward Sergio Aguero and midfielder Fernandinho sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for his second dismissal for violent conduct this season, following a high and late challenge on David Luiz. Fernandinho, who clashed with Fabregas in the scuffle, will serve a three-match ban. City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's part in the incident, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Cymru a rhannau eraill o'r DU mae cyfraddau goresgyn canser gwaethaf yn y byd datblygedig. Mae cynllun peilot yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd yn canolbwyntio ar cleifion mae eu meddygon teulu yn amau sydd â chanser ond ddim yn dangos unrhyw arwyddion neu symptomau brys. Y pryder yw cleifion sydd ddim gyda symptomau clir yn disgwyl am gyfnod rhy hir am ddiagnosis. Bydd 40 o feddygon yng Nghwm Cynon yn credu efallai bod rhywbeth o'i le yn gallu cyfeirio cleifion at ganolfan ddiagnostig yn Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg o fewn saith diwrnod, gyda'r gobaith y byddai rhyw chwe chlaf yr wythnos yn cael eu gweld a profion gwahanol. Mae'r treialon wedi eu datblygu ers i arbenigwyr o Gymru ddychwelyd o Aarhus, ac fe aeth Denmarc ati i sefydlu canolfannau diagnostig oherwydd pryderon am eu cyfraddau goresgyn. Bydd y cynllun yn tawelu meddwl claf a hefyd yn cyflymu'r broses, gyda'r gobaith y bydd cleifion yn cael diagnosis cynnar os oes ganddyn nhw ganser. Os bydd cynllun peilot Cwm Cynon yn llwyddiannus, bydd gweddill byrddau iechyd yr ardal yn cynnig yr un gwasanaeth yn y misoedd wedyn.

England leveled the series at Old Trafford, securing a win with a day to spare and setting up their second biggest victory over Pakistan in terms of runs. They scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second, also taking four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it as good an innings as he had seen. Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch offering little assistance to bowlers. England's strong batting, discipline, and good bowling were highlighted, with Geoffrey Boycott noting their quality and predicting they will win again. Only Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq have passed 50 in the first two Tests, and Misbah expressed disappointment, citing issues with confidence and shot selection.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde takes on head coach responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde and is in advanced discussions to confirm the full management team. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, as the summer of 2017 presents opportunities for Welsh coaches and should help Welsh rugby in the future.

Hull City secured a win against Southampton, ending a six-game losing streak, with Snodgrass scoring and assisting in a two-minute second-half turnaround. The hosts had lost starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries, but Snodgrass' return from the bench brought urgency. Despite Southampton pushing for an equalizer, David Marshall made key saves, and Clucas cleared a corner at the goalline in added time. The victory was significant for Hull, who remain in the bottom three, while Southampton had previously celebrated a Europa League win.

A crash occurred at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist killed in the collision lived locally, with no further details released, and the tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses to come forward. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, aiming to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. This move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, with the opposition leader Zoran Zaev calling it illegal and urging protests in Skopje. The crisis stems from recordings showing ministers allegedly plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder, with Zaev accusing the government of wiretapping and corruption. The government denies these accusations, instead claiming Zaev is trying to destabilize the country.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking, with Swansea aiming to appoint a new boss soon, favoring ex-Derby manager Paul Clement. Curtis believes the Swans have lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, with constant management changes and a diluted "Swansea Way." He thinks the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds new signings of the club's history, emphasizing the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the area.

Dagenham, known as the Daggers, needed a win to keep their survival hopes alive, but Armand Gnanduillet's goal relegate them and keep Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who first reached the Football League in 2007, now return to the National League under John Still, the same manager who took them to League One. The team has the worst goal difference in League Two, conceding more goals this season and struggling in attack, with Jamie Cureton scoring fewer goals compared to last season. Still is committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion from the National League next season. Victory leaves Orient two points from the play-off spots, following player-manager Kevin Nolan's removal. Leyton Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, discusses the challenges of losing two managers and the need to win games for the play-offs. Dagenham's manager, John Still, reflects on the lack of organization and discipline leading to their defeat, noting the club's difficulty in responding to setbacks this year.

Steven Gerrard, the former Reds captain, is returning to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. Klopp mentioned having a good chat with Gerrard, who wants to be a manager in the future, and described the appointment as wonderful news. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998, leaving Anfield after the 2014-15 season to join LA Galaxy, and retired in November after a 19-year career. He had been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but felt the opportunity came too soon. Gerrard is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, required to manage in the Premier League.

McManus scored from close range on the quarter-hour mark to open the scoring, and Ross Forbes' deflected strike quickly doubled Morton's lead. Kyle McAusland pulled Alloa back into the game before half-time. However, another McManus finish and a goal by Denny Johnstone late on secured a comfortable win for the hosts.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham, which have now closed, with owners being investigated for running illegal schools. Anyone operating such schools could face a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern that these cases might be the "tip of the iceberg," with children at risk of abuse or radicalisation. The government is consulting on more regulation for places teaching over 6 to 8 hours a week, and a team of six inspectors has been funded to investigate illegal schools. While most visited places have been in Muslim communities, attention may also turn to similar centres by other groups. The education secretary intends to go further, asking Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools it has identified.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh and is part of proposals to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the potential for the Scottish Borders to become a region of distilling excellence, noting that their gin production is on a smaller scale compared to other distilleries in development. The gin aims to capture the local flavour palette and Borders 'terroir' using wild food from the Teviot valley. John Henderson of Born in the Borders sees the gin distillery as a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site, appreciating the use of Borders botanicals in line with their ethos of local sourcing. The gin takes its name from Lilliard, a legendary Borders heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, chosen to reflect their landscape and strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam died when Gary Green reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm in August 2013. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed. Leeds Crown Court heard that Green had previously admitted failing to ensure the safety of others and was prosecuted under health and safety legislation, as the incident occurred on private land. He was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed that the family had been "changed forever" and emphasized that it is not okay for anyone to be drunk and drive, whether on public roads or private land. An HSE investigation found Green's behavior to be reckless, describing the case as extremely tragic.

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguay striker, can now train and play in friendly matches after his club Barcelona confirmed he will join the first team's training session. The public presentation of Suarez as a new Barcelona player will be on Monday at the Camp Nou, though it is not known if he will play in Monday's game with Mexico's Club Leon. A Cas ruling allows him to participate in all football-related activities but still prevents him from playing in organized matches. He must serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games, with his competitive Barcelona debut likely at Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez will be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. His lawyers argued that Fifa's suspension for biting Giorgio Chiellini was too strong, and Cas confirmed the sanctions but said preventing football activity was excessive. Suarez's legal team considers the appeal a success, claiming Fifa misapplied its rules. Additionally, he can attend matches and take part in promotional activities.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race by beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania, who was carrying his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. They trained hard, running around an athletics track, and faced strong competition, especially from the Lithuanians. The event involved a 380-metre course with hurdles like haystacks, a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Competitors included various combinations, not just married pairs. Rich and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond stated that job roles would change when the paper system for car tax discs is scrapped in October, addressing concerns about job losses in a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges. The minister mentioned that the introduction of a direct debit scheme and withdrawal of the tax disc might lead to a natural reduction in refunds and necessitate changes to job roles, with any reductions managed through redeploying to other growth areas. Mr Hedges welcomed these assurances, acknowledging the advantages of monthly direct debits and the absence of needing to show a tax disc, while expressing disappointment over reduced job opportunities at the DVLA.

Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is facing pressure from European institutions to withdraw three laws, two of which have already been passed. These include tight controls on asylum seekers, a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University, and a draft legislation on NGOs expected to go before parliament. The EU objects to these laws, with concerns about compatibility with EU law, especially regarding the housing of asylum seekers in secured shipping containers. Hungary's minister, Mr. Szijjarto, stated that the EU should not interfere with domestic issues and that Poland would veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights.

The star will play Mrs. Potts, a housekeeper turned teapot, in the film. Kevin Kline has signed on to play Maurice, the father of Belle. The film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, with Emma Watson cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times, had been diagnosed with multiple cancers, referred to as the "full English" of cancers, and had been undergoing chemotherapy. He was described as "a giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper, with his final column about coming to terms with his diagnosis to be featured in the Sunday Times. Gill passed away, and his death shocked colleagues, as he was known for his wit, fearless writing, and compassion. Tributes were paid by writers, broadcasters, and journalists, highlighting his impact and unique style. His writing often caused controversy, with past comments leading to outrage and censure. Gill, who overcame dyslexia, had a career in writing, including art reviews and work for the Sunday Times. He was married twice, first to author Cressida Connolly and later to Home Secretary Amber Rudd, and had children with both. His illness prompted his engagement to his partner, Nicola Formby, with whom he also had two children.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a rapper in Ulan Bator, was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomatic officer, being hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face, resulting in his spending about 10 days in a coma. The Russian embassy is investigating but called local press reports "distorted." Sukhbaatar was wearing a red deel with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol pre-dating Hitler, which he emphasized is not a hate symbol in his country. His father, lawyer, and a band member denied reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show. The suspect, not yet identified or arrested, is a Russian diplomatic officer, with a police spokesman stating the injury was not serious and that it's not true the suspect wasn't arrested due to diplomatic immunity.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration against the airport's expansion plans, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, and the individuals involved will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police has stated that airport security will be reviewed.

Glamorgan's total was led by Nick Selman's second first-class century, a return to form after a string of low scores. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured wickets fell regularly, with Aneurin Donald's quick 36 being the next best contribution. The day ended evenly balanced, with Glamorgan scrambling for a consolation bonus point. Nick Selman expressed satisfaction with getting some runs, acknowledging the slow wicket and challenges of opening in county cricket. Gloucestershire's seamer Matt Taylor noted the bowlers had something on offer, aiming to hit the top of off-stump and taking satisfaction in bowling Glamorgan out for 220.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, raising fears of a planned murder bid involving an ambush of police over a non-existent crime. Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He intended to make a false report to police so that officers would come to the scene, with plans to shoot them on the Dee Estuary, as outlined by prosecutors. The threats were made twice, late at night while Hughes was drunk. The judge was informed of Hughes's previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and remanded him in custody pending sentence. Hughes's legal team previously stated he had no intention to kill himself or carry out threats against police. North Wales Police was especially concerned as Hughes was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, which he was later cleared of.

Surrey, after being reduced to 8-2, posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a 130-run stand. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, which included Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan made 68 but was the last to go as Yorkshire were all out for 236. Despite an ideal start, Yorkshire lost to Surrey, with Meaker turning the game by taking key wickets. Surrey's captain praised Davies and Foakes for their magnificent partnership, while Yorkshire's captain expressed being gutted, noting they hadn't been good enough when it mattered, despite the bowlers' exceptional performance.

A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST as a pump on board couldn't handle the water coming in. Holyhead coastguards reported the issue, and the RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir will not be with the Scotland team at next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, as her exams are in May and the Commonwealths are in April. She expressed being gutted about missing the opportunity to run for Scotland but emphasized the importance of getting her degree. Despite this, she believes she has at least two, maybe three more Olympics in her and mentions the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. Muir also shared her happiness after achieving a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in a race, feeling there is a lot of potential for her future in running.

Robbie Savage discusses why Liverpool are far from repeating last season's title challenge, noting their struggles in the transfer market, particularly up front, with Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini not being good enough replacements for Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge. The team lacks intensity, pressing, and first-half goals compared to last season, and their set-pieces have become less effective. Defensively, they have not improved despite spending on players like Dejan Lovren, and their goalkeeper, Simon Mignolet, does not command his box enough. Savage also addresses Steven Gerrard's mental and physical battle to secure a long-term future with the Reds, emphasizing that Gerrard's desire will keep him going despite past disappointments.

A £45m facility at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus in honor of the renowned writer, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. Council leader Douglas Reid expressed delight in preserving the William McIlvanney name, noting the writer's passion for good education for young people. McIlvanney, who became an English teacher before writing full time in 1975, gained recognition with his first novel, "Remedy Is None," and earned the title of "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He wrote the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works, was an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster, and contributed to political and sporting life in Scotland. The novelist died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near the swimming pool in the town had been evacuated, with residents advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside. An exclusion zone remains on the river as experts make safe a British sea mine, thought to date from the 1940s or 1950s, spotted on Monday. The evacuation affected three streets, with safety advice given to those within 500m of the device, and there was also a half-mile exclusion zone at sea, preventing small boat owners from sailing. Ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay faced disruption. Authorities stressed the evacuation was precautionary, with no immediate danger to the community. Due to the mine's deterioration, it was decided to move it to a safer place before dealing with it.

Funding for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, badminton, and cycling, has been cut, with badminton's funding removal described as "incomprehensible" and having a "catastrophic impact." A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, slightly less than the Rio Games allocation. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo, aiming to maintain the success from Rio. Badminton, which earned a bronze in the men's doubles, is the only sport that achieved a podium in the summer to have its funding removed. Judo, which also had a similar target and claimed one bronze, has seen its funding increased slightly. UK Sport emphasizes the need to prioritize investments to protect and enhance medal potential, with funding for new Olympic and Paralympic sports yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage objected to the development's scale in a designated conservation area, stating it would cause "severe harm." Councillors voted seven to three in favor, arguing it would help tourism and improve living for older people, with David Kelsey noting the buildings were no longer "necessarily functional." The project, by The East Cliff Project LLP, will replace Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels with a 90-room hotel and apartment buildings. While the council received 246 supporting letters, forty-nine residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, saying the hotels still give a sense of the area's historic character.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely during a night out in Brecon, leading to his unconscious body being found by police. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The incident occurred as Pte Boyd was returning to barracks after training exercises, with CCTV showing him being punched, going to the ground, and beaten until he no longer moved. Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. The family tribute described Pte Boyd as full of life and highlighted the unbearable pain of his loss, noting that the community's outpouring of love represents the strongest people in Brecon.

Andrew Travers left the authority by "mutual agreement" after an error that led to voters being initially turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough due to their names missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, with the council apologizing for the problems and offering emergency proxy votes to affected residents. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily while longer-term arrangements are put in place. Mr. Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the issues, and the council's review will conclude by the end of May, looking at the "appropriateness" of arrangements for the EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead beat Wrexham in a match where Josh Gillies scored a fine free-kick to put the Tynesiders ahead, and Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham before half-time with an equally fine set-piece. Ryan Bowman then scored a fine winner for Gateshead, heading Jamie Chandler's cross into the net. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby noted their improvement in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, citing their second half not being as good as the first. The match ended with Gateshead at 2 and Wrexham at 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project, in collaboration with Airbus, aims to create a network of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to deliver broadband links globally, especially to every school. This requires a shift in satellite manufacturing towards high volume and low cost, using assembly line methods similar to car and plane factories, with the goal of producing three units per shift at under a million dollars each. The first assembly line is in Toulouse, France, with more in Florida, and the project involves a significant rocket campaign, including over 20 Soyuz vehicles. OneWeb and Airbus are not alone in planning mega-constellations, but they believe their concept has a first-mover advantage, having raised $1.7bn in equity. The UK Space Agency is involved in licensing, and there is a focus on debris mitigation, with OneWeb committing to de-orbit satellites within two years and adding hardware for reliability. Not all spacecraft will require this mass production approach, as some will still need bespoke treatment.

Mr Swinney stated that the UK government's recent spending review has placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, with the Scottish government arguing that cuts since 2010 and the latest review will result in a 12.5% lower discretionary budget in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. He emphasized that the UK government could have reduced debt and deficit without such cuts, and now Scotland must face the reality of the chancellor's decision, facing tough choices. Mr Swinney assured that schools, hospitals, and the police service would not be sacrificed to austerity, highlighting past achievements like more police, lower crime, better schools, tuition-free university, and a record health budget. The UK government's Scotland Office responded, noting the Scottish government will have £390m more spending next year and that the block grant will be almost £30bn, suggesting this is a better deal than the constitutional alternative. Labour's Jackie Baillie called for Swinney to back up anti-austerity posturing with real action in the upcoming budget.

People with severe disabilities and their families often face challenges due to a lack of suitable toilet facilities, leaving them feeling isolated. Changing Places toilets, which have enhanced features and more space, are recommended for larger buildings but are not compulsory. Campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham, are pushing to make these toilets mandatory in building regulations to better meet the needs of those who require two carers or a hoist. There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, and they are included in the Building Standards guidelines as a recommendation. Efforts are focused on making them compulsory for newly built larger complexes like shopping centers and sports stadiums.
