The boy's mother expresses concern about the situation, as the system has isolated him and fears similar issues for other families. The Education Authority is reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability close to where children reside, with this work ongoing to assist placements from 2016.

Newport Gwent Dragons are facing a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union, who view Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. County has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League, and they expect their contract to be honored. A vote on the WRU's takeover is scheduled for Tuesday, 9 May. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. County is currently two points clear of the League Two relegation and can clinch survival this weekend. Relegation to the National League would be a significant blow, as Newport secured promotion back to the Football League in 2013.

The country was declared free of a virus that killed almost 4,000 people in the past 18 months. A person recounts being kidnapped by RUF rebels at 15, trained to use a gun, and subjected to threats and atrocities during the civil war. They escaped, faced challenges in the capital, and met a preacher who inspired them to contribute to rebuilding the nation. When the Ebola crisis came to Sierra Leone in 2014, they, along with others, developed a clinic to address the situation. Their efforts included education, supporting people with food and items, and setting up an Ebola treatment unit, which saved many lives. They emphasize investing in young people to change the world.

About 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs were at risk of being auctioned to help pay off a pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign launched in September met its target in a month, allowing the collection to remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. This outcome was described as "fantastic news," with the collection being important for Staffordshire and significant in charting Britain's cultural development and defining national identity.

Dan Groves mentioned that the "finer points" of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of the club are yet to be released, with The Sun reporting that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, have been recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, surprised many by announcing a one-year extension of his term, rather than staying until 2021 or leaving as originally intended in 2018. This decision was driven by personal reasons, particularly the timing for his family to return home to Canada, as one daughter will be finishing A-levels and another completing GCSEs in 2018. He emphasized that the choice was entirely personal, not influenced by government policy or criticism of the Bank's forecasts. The extension allows him to stay until the Article 50 process of Britain's exit from the EU is complete, after which a new Governor will take over.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew the match at 1-1. Blackpool scored first with Nathan Delfouneso jinking past a player and delivering a chip into the area, where Jamille Matt turned the ball home. Colchester equalized from a corner as Kurtis Guthrie prodded in after a goalmouth scramble. Both teams had chances to re-take the lead, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred missing a header from a corner. Colchester finished with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was shown a straight red for a bad tackle in injury time.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, aims to help children in P6 and P7 cope with change, particularly preparing them for the stresses of the transfer test and big educational life changes. It includes interactive workshops focusing on emotional wellbeing, encouraging help-seeking, and identifying support sources, while also providing teachers with basic training in promoting emotional wellbeing. The initiative was launched at Carrick Primary School, with the goal of being rolled out across Northern Ireland schools. The programme addresses the anxiety around transitioning to secondary school, noting that this period is particularly stressful for children. It emphasizes strategies for protecting children from stress and helping them cope with change, aligning with the need to strengthen the resilience of young people in the education system.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the disused Fawley power station chimney into the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, making it the centrepiece of a "merchant city" development. The power station, which closed in 2013 after more than 40 years of operation, was commissioned in 1971 and could power one million homes. The Â£1bn development includes a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. An application for outline planning permission is due later this year, with building potentially starting in 2018. The company emphasizes that the chimney is a signature piece of infrastructure, already present, allowing for a spectacular transformation with relatively little investment.

A 23-year-old earned GB's second medal at the Hong Kong championships, taking bronze in a race where Adrian Teklinski of Poland won gold and Lucass Liss of Germany got silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB were beaten to the bronze medal by Italy. Elsewhere, Britain's Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and the women's team pursuit finished fifth in the heats, failing to make the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker, an Olympic gold medallist, joined a young squad in the quartet but they couldn't compete for a medal. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round and is scheduled to compete in two more events.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, is returning to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes, describing it as a brief return. Following her surprise return to Albert Square, Dame Barbara announced her character would be killed off, with Peggy set to die from cancer in emotional spring scenes. Kemp, having played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, will return to reunite the Mitchell family with their mother for the last time. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlights this as an opportunity to showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best, with Grant Mitchell being one of the soap's most memorable characters.

Sadio Mane scored twice within 138 seconds as second-placed Spurs disappointed at Anfield. Pochettino expressed concerns, stating that starting the game poorly makes it difficult to fight for the Premier League, highlighting a lack of desire to win. He mentioned that if Chelsea extends their lead by beating Burnley, it could be a big problem. Spurs have struggled on the road, with only two wins since 24 September and poor results against top-six rivals. Pochettino noted that the team in the first 45 minutes wasn't ready to fight for the league. Danny Murphy commented on the Spurs' performance, saying they were all over the place despite having a good defensive record, and suggested they should have stuck with their back three formation against big sides. He also pointed out a lack of pace and a different mindset when playing away from home, emphasizing the need for improvement.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but held on to Rivers State and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP failing to secure a national spread of votes. The APC did not win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. Elections were marred by some violence, especially in Rivers and other southern states, but overall were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP, which had been in power for 16 years, faces a period of introspection and rebuilding after allegations of corruption and failure to address an Islamist-led insurgency.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival can use an app to trigger online information from items like signs and posters, offering videos and band interviews viewable on phones and tablets. The festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan. This augmented reality experience is an extra feature to enhance enjoyment, allowing people worldwide to interact with the festival and capture its atmosphere at any time. The message will be updated before and during the event, enabling instant access to information, interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the unique festival.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated, with Park View Educational Trust possibly being removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, face warnings about losing funding unless concerns are addressed. A head teacher from a Trojan Horse school mentioned feeling alone and targeted by parents, with everything changing when the Trojan Horse letter news broke. The watchdog published reports into schools allegedly targeted for a hardline Muslim takeover, with five, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. Birmingham City Council plans to work with Saltley School, in special measures, to install a temporary governing board. Education minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about Park View School's operation, criticizing the trust for failing to promote pupils' development and intending to terminate funding agreements. Similar actions were outlined for Nansen Primary and Oldknow Academy, with demands to address breaches, including ending less favourable treatment of non-Muslims and segregation. Parents have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and wanting to invite Education Secretary Michael Gove for an open meeting about the findings.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years for allegedly plotting to topple the government in Tehran, with her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticizing the UK government for a lack of action. The appeal against her term is happening in "secret" and is being held in Tehran. Since her arrest at Tehran Airport last April, she has spent time in solitary confinement, and her two-year-old daughter Gabriella has remained in Iran after the government confiscated her passport, being looked after by her grandparents. Mr. Ratcliffe believes his wife is being used as a bargaining chip in a diplomatic row between Iran and the UK, and the appeal outcome could see her sentence quashed, reduced, or increased. He also mentioned his daughter has lost her English and is now fluent in Farsi, with conversations requiring translation or being very physical. Amnesty International UK called Mrs. Zaghari-Ratcliffe a "prisoner of conscience" held for peacefully exercising her right to freedom of expression and association.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after having a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court claims that the conduct of eye specialist Honey Rose was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal," with her alleged failure to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation at the heart of the case. A build-up of fluid in his brain increased pressure in his skull, ultimately leading to his death. The prosecution alleges that Vinnie's death was preventable if Ms. Rose had done her job properly. The trial continues, and Ms. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter.

Clive Weatherhogg set up meetings between a woman and a man found through an adult website, filmed them having sex, and sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was found guilty of coercing the woman into sexual activity and intercourse with the man between 10 September, 2013, and 17 September the following year, as well as intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on 25 December, 2014. Weatherhogg, who had denied the charges, was placed on the sex offenders register and remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. The judge emphasized that the sentence should reflect society's abhorrence at such conduct, noting that Weatherhogg, a first offender, posed a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in Greater Noida, with Stuart Thompson hitting 56, Gary Wilson (41 no), and captain William Porterfield (39) contributing valuable runs. However, it was not enough as Afghanistan, aided by Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47), reached 171-4 with two overs to spare. Ireland faced an early setback with Paul Stirling dismissed for a duck, and despite efforts, they fell short of their target. The sides are set to meet again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday. Additionally, Ireland lost paceman Boyd Rankin for the T20s due to a back problem, though he is expected to return for the five ODIs against Afghanistan starting on 15 March.

Barcelona insists they have not committed any offence, despite a judge ruling there was sufficient evidence against them to continue investigations into the Neymar transfer. The club made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to address possible divergent interpretations of tax responsibility and to defend their reputation, stating they remain convinced the original tax payment was in line with fiscal obligations. The case has not yet been confirmed to be dropped after this payment.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao. Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to work with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the killings. The UK detectives have completed their work and will return to compile a report and update the families. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the police investigation, including DNA sample verification and mistreatment allegations. Post-mortem examinations showed Mr. Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds, with DNA found on her matching the suspects' samples.

VR is being embedded in reality to enhance understanding of the world, used by journalists, teachers, healthcare workers, and retailers. The UK's National Autistic Society created a VR film to help people understand autism, touring it in shopping centers and offering it for schools. Alzheimer's Research UK also released a VR film to put the public in the shoes of someone with dementia. Virtual reality is becoming a tool for selling, with examples like Ikea's app for virtual kitchens, which even included virtual meatballs. In healthcare, VR is used as a teaching aid and to treat phobias, with a surgeon offering live virtual surgeries. Education is also adopting VR, as seen in Google's Expeditions program and a VR app being trialed at Imperial College to improve language skills. However, cash-strapped schools may struggle with the hardware and computing power needed for VR.

The "black box" of the Su-24 jet was opened in Moscow, with Nikolai Primak, head of the Russian investigation, indicating that flight information might be missing. Data from the box could help resolve the dispute over the jet's location when it was hit, with an analysis expected next week. The downing of the jet caused a crisis in relations between Russia and Turkey, with Moscow imposing sanctions. Turkey claims the jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace, while Russia says it was shot down within Syrian airspace. The Su-24 was shot down by F-16 fighters on 24 November, with both crew members ejecting, the pilot killed by militants, and the navigator rescued. A Russian marine sent to rescue the crew was also killed, and a helicopter destroyed. Russia has demanded an apology from Turkey and imposed sanctions, including a ban on package holidays, potentially costing Turkey billions of dollars.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with a victory likely securing their place. Evans, who has experienced play-off losses before, is determined not to miss out again, as the outcome of Friday's game and the return fixture in Reykjavik could decide the group top. Iceland, ranked one place above the Scots, are also unbeaten. Evans, part of a squad with many players outside Scotland, believes the benefits of having more players in top leagues help the national team as they aim for a first major finals.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform, set up by the Scottish government and Cosla, found no "magic bullet" to cure defects in the council tax system, which has built-in problems and has not been modified, storing up difficulties. The review, led by Prof Kenneth Gibb, noted that property tax is used by almost all OECD countries and seen as a "good tax" but generates confusion and some perceive it as unfair. A local income tax, considered fairer, creates difficulties for local authorities with fluctuating income and limited ability to vary tax rates. The commission will hold a public consultation before publishing its report in the autumn, as the Scottish government considers the current council tax system unfair and awaits the report to examine fairer alternatives.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification process to prevent third-party software from infiltrating iCloud, following suggestions that such tools had been used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. This security measure requires an extra step after entering a username and password on a new device, involving a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile number or via the Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases are blocked, with a 14-character recovery key available for regaining access if a trusted device is lost or stolen. While Apple had offered this system before, it had not been in play for the back-up service, allowing attackers to download data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple's changes now guard against this technique, with the owner of Elcomsoft acknowledging the implementation as secure. However, concerns remain about the recovery key being hard to remember and potentially stolen. Security experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be the default, not just recommended, and Apple plans to more aggressively encourage its use along with stronger passwords.

UKIP, which won May's election, spent £2,956,737 on their campaign, while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems £1,580,575, and Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The figures cover the campaign period from 23 January to polling day, 22 May. UKIP's spending was 68p per vote, Labour 26p, Conservatives 79p, and the Lib Dems £1.45. The Green Party, fourth, spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. Altogether, the six highest-spending parties, including the SNP's £267,372, spent £9,347,087 on campaigning, with all but Labour spending more than during the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals, possibly facing his old club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams and has had previous spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his move pending international clearance. Nicholson describes Anderson as a leader-type and mentions Keating is young, a bit raw, but hungry to show his abilities. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day and was later pronounced dead, having suffered a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority noted that such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite past symptoms of post-race ataxia, including overheating and wobbling, the horse had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms on Saturday. The report concludes that the horse was the victim of a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack, with questions raised about a potential link to his previous condition.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was emotional after veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil bid farewell to the parliament, and again when Mr. Salmond said goodbye, as both are standing down ahead of the election on 5 May. Mr. Salmond, in his valedictory address, reiterated that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," and emphasized the need for the parliament to take on greater responsibility for Scotland's governance. He welcomed the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but felt it did not fulfill unionist pledges from the referendum campaign. Mr. McNeil, in his final speech, warned that Holyrood has things to learn from Westminster, especially regarding the committee system, stressing the importance of accountability and scrutiny. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also leaving Holyrood.

The star will play Mrs. Potts, a housekeeper turned teapot, in the film. Kevin Kline is set to play Maurice, the father of Belle, with Emma Watson cast as Belle. Dan Stevens from Downton Abbey will portray the Beast, and Luke Evans will co-star as Gaston, the villain. Josh Gad will be Gaston's sidekick, LeFou. Bill Condon, known for directing Dreamgirls and the last two Twilight films, will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is scheduled for release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will reveal its intentions at a meeting with victims' relatives regarding the 1989 stadium disaster that fatally injured ninety-six football fans. New inquests concluded the fans had been unlawfully killed, and files of evidence relating to 23 suspects, including 15 for the Operation Resolve investigation and eight for a police conduct probe, were referred to the CPS. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall, whose son died, will be informed of decisions by Sue Hemming at a private meeting in Warrington. Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, described the waiting as a long struggle, expressing that the families seek accountability and are determined to never give up, acknowledging it will be a day of mixed emotions.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being hurled over the wall, with a former inmate noting it is notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident reported witnessing such events four times in two weeks, expressing concern but not fear. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges staff efforts to stop contraband but admits more must be done, with the Justice Secretary seeking ways to ensure prisons have the necessary tools. The Ministry also mentions laws introduced that could jail those smuggling packages over prison walls for up to two years, while denying evidence of drones being used at the Chelmsford site, despite a claim from the former inmate.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries when Brian Wright, 55, struck her outside Bedford Road Lower School last December. Wright, who claims he was blinded by the setting sun, admits to hitting Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He expressed remorse, stating he had turned her "world upside down" and thought of nothing else since the incident. At the time, Blackburn was on duty, wearing appropriate clothing, and was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road when Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light. The court heard that traffic in the other direction had stopped, but Wright did not, resulting in the collision. The trial continues.

Muir will not be with the Scotland team at next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, as her exams are in May and the Commonwealths are in April. She expressed being gutted about missing the opportunity to run for Scotland but emphasized the importance of getting her degree. Despite this, she believes she has at least two, maybe three more Olympics in her and mentioned the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. Muir also shared her happiness after achieving a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in a race, feeling there is a lot of potential for her future in running.

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a site in Chapelizod, Dublin, has started, involving excavations and expected to take weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed his disappearance, using enhanced CCTV footage showing him talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. The man was also seen following Mr. Deely on Haddington Road, but has not yet been identified. Gardaí have renewed their appeal for the man to come forward.

Del Potro secured a victory over the Swiss player with a score of 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3, despite being ranked 165th after missing over two years due to injury. He will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young, being in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. The match saw Wawrinka take the opening set, but Del Potro fought back to win the second and the thrilling third set in a tie-break, ultimately taking the fourth set for victory. Additionally, Australia's Nick Kyrgios, also in the same half as Murray, came from two sets to one down to beat Dustin Brown in a rain-affected second-round match. Spanish 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez will play Kyrgios in the third round, with the winner facing either Murray or John Millman in the last 16.

Tunisia faced possible expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after complaining to Caf about an incident during this year's Nations Cup, but a rapprochement was achieved following a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Meanwhile, Morocco was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban and reduced a fine. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to fears over importing the Ebola virus. The Tunisians had a row with Caf over a contentious penalty in their quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a furious letter and a demand for an apology to avoid disqualification. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 event seemed in doubt until the situation was resolved.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling, aiming for a result of the fourth row of the grid or decent points. Despite their past greatness, including a partnership with Honda that led to significant successes like winning 15 of 16 races in 1988, the team has faced a slump, particularly since 2013 when they lost their way on chassis design. Now, while they have regained some form with the car, problems persist with the Honda power-unit. The team has experienced cycles of triumph and decline, with past issues like being fined for possessing Ferrari technical information and a 'lie-gate' scandal. Ron Dennis, who took control after a dip in form, has returned to address the slide, believing success will return and that McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony in F1. However, for now, belief is all they have, resting on the successful end of a great driver's career and the team's reputation.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, with police finding several people still at the bar. Till receipts showed alcohol being served as late as 04:49 BST, leading the judge to order the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. A defence solicitor noted that licensing laws were not strictly adhered to, and the premises were not run properly, operating well into the morning. The judge described Ms O'Neill's record as "appalling" and expressed concern about lacking power to impose a custodial sentence, calling it as bad a case as he had come across. Ms O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Mr Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, hitting eight to eclipse his previous best of 272 made in a single season, as he scored 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry, who entered the game four shy of his mark, teamed with Klay Thompson, who scored 26 points, to bring the Warriors back from 13 points down. Elsewhere, the Chicago Bulls easily overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat, delivering a significant blow to Miami's playoff hopes.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic met YouTube star Bas van Velzen at Melwood, initially thinking he was a competition winner who had earned a meeting and dead-ball masterclass. However, it became clear that van Velzen, a Dutch free-kick specialist, was not a regular fan as he showcased his skills in front of goal. Van Velzen, known for uploading free-kick videos, wowed the Liverpool quartet and even had a last surprise for Balotelli by unveiling his infamous slogan.

Women who carry the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed, a procedure known as an oophorectomy. A study found that this surgery cuts their risk of dying from breast cancer by more than 60 per cent, with a significant drop of 62 per cent in breast cancer death for those with a BRCA1 mutation. The protective effect is apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasts for 15 years, especially for women with oestrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. The study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with mutated genes, where nearly half underwent oophorectomy after diagnosis, showing a 65 per cent reduction in death from all causes associated with the surgery. Researchers suggest that oophorectomy should become part of the treatment discussion at the time of diagnosis for BRCA mutation carriers with early stage breast cancers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed when an Amtrak train hit them on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, shortly before 10 am. The train, heading north from Charlotte to New York City, was on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train continued its route after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. A man who met the pair while collecting scrap metal mentioned they may have lived in a homeless camp and had a grocery cart.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, he is now facing deportation, living in the U.S. illegally. His work aided in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, but the DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he went public with his plight. Toro fears for his life if sent back to Colombia, stating he would be dead within the first four hours. He remains in limbo, trying to secure a green card or passport, and cannot collect social security benefits until he does.

A U.S. body regulating internet addresses is considering actions against a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new 'sucks' domain name to charge high fees from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies to protect their reputations. Purchased names include YouTube.sucks, Bing.sucks, Visa.sucks, Bankofamerica.sucks, Yahoo.sucks, and others. Kevin Spacey is reportedly among those paying to have his name removed from a 'sucks' domain. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has sent a letter to U.S. and Canadian regulators to check if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. The company initially had ICANN's approval for the top-level domain but is now backtracking after complaints from an advisory panel. Vox Populi began accepting registrations for 'sucks' domains on March 30, with resellers selling names for around $2,499 a year. The advisory body has called the rollout a 'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory.' ICANN is seeking remedies if regulators find the company's actions illegal.

A mother of a baby boy was arrested 27 years after his body was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond. Police exhumed the boy's body from his grave in Norfolk after the case came up for periodical review, and a DNA sample eventually led them to his mother. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained the baby had been stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. She placed the dead baby in the pond in the village of Weasenham St Peter on June 5, 1988, before it was found by teenagers. The boy's body was exhumed, with DNA samples leading police to the mother, who admitted concealing the pregnancy and delivering the baby by herself. Police ruled out foul play, and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides on potential charges. The baby was reburied at Weasenham St Peter church, with a new headstone naming him Peter after the church.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving car. Hicks had objected when Young, mistakenly believing he was planning to avoid paying the fare, drove him back to the rank to teach him a lesson. The incident led to Hicks jumping from the vehicle while it was traveling at over 20mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries, epilepsy, and the need for round-the-clock care from his mother. The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The compensation amount is expected to be around 50 per cent of what the family requested, with a further £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both sides have been given permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the exact payment.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas as several storms brought reports of twisters, with spotters noting a tornado near Goddard, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. Nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as the most deadly and dangerous. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas, including near Aetna. A possible tornado also touched down in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage, flooding, and a fallen tree. Unusual dark clouds were observed in Leadington, and a Twitter user in Farmington reported baseball-sized hail. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi river valley, Tennessee river valley, and near the southern great lakes.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight clash in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. Rockhold plans to be the bull to Machida's matador, cutting him off and making him fight his style, as he believes Machida has a small avenue to win on the feet. Meanwhile, Machida is confident he can apply his style and technique to stop Rockhold and earn a title shot, feeling well-prepared after eight weeks of training.

An aeroplane touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly. The light general aviation aircraft approached the aero acres residential airpark, and the video maker observed that the landing gear had not been deployed before touchdown, causing the plane to scratch along the tarmac. The pilot re-engaged the engines and took off back into the air, with the propellers ricocheting off the ground. Despite the damage, the pilot, Chris Georgaklis, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and land safely. The FAA is investigating the incident, with the most common cause of such a gear-up landing being human error, when a pilot forgets to deploy the landing gear before touchdown.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Touré's performance but vowed to support the Manchester City midfielder until the end of the season. Despite criticism, Pellegrini dismissed the idea of giving Touré a rest and acknowledged his underperformance. Sportsmail revealed that City would listen to offers for Touré as they look to overhaul an ageing squad. Pellegrini also faces questions over his own future, while City goalkeeper Joe Hart insisted players should take responsibility, noting that the manager has the dressing room's backing. Additionally, Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as others by moving to Manchester City, amid interest from the club in signing the West Ham left back.

A Sicilian mafia fugitive, Domenico Rancadore, dubbed the godfather of Uxbridge, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. He was given a seven-year sentence by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra and was set to be extradited. However, it emerged that his case expired last October, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still be heard by the Italian supreme court. Rancadore's solicitor expressed confidence that the Italian government will withdraw their extradition application, allowing him to live in peace in England with his family.

Mr Mole, AP McCoy's mount in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in a seven-runner line-up, bracketed with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre. Trained by Paul Nicholls, Mr Mole will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, with his book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey not finalised until Friday morning. Other runners in the chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of a girl murdered 40 years ago, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter, Marcia, who was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband had advised her against seeing the body and photos. After declining for several decades, even after Barrett's conviction 33 years later, Ritter asked to see the photos last year. She viewed them on a police investigator's laptop, describing the horror of seeing her daughter's swollen face, vomit, pulled-out hair, and blood on her scalp. Ritter expressed a desire for revenge, saying, "if I had a gun I'd kill him!" The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006, with DNA matching him to the crime. He was found guilty of second-degree murder and received a 44-year sentence.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, considering it a career-long goal to achieve what only a handful of players have. He views his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, learning much about himself and his game. McIlroy is hoping to claim his first green jacket and become one of the six players to win all four major titles, with Augusta being a course he feels he can do very well at and potentially win multiple times on. Despite having just one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, he is looking to emulate the likes of Jack Nicklaus. Additionally, he hopes to use the golf course as his sanctuary from the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta, similar to how it helped him last year amid personal and legal distractions.

It was a busy week for trending stories, including four rainbows appearing in the New York area after heavy rain, with Amanda Curtis capturing the moment. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming common but now faces a crackdown on vice. RDJ grew agitated when asked about his private life by a UK interviewer. A new trend involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar to look like Kylie Jenner, with a hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge. A 102-year-old, Alice Barker, went back in time with filmmakers' help. A prom-posal referencing bombs led to accusations of racism against school administrators. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," drawing social media interest, and Johnny Depp appears nearly unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer. Other trends included a creative way to announce pregnancy referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and a military dad photobombing his son.

New figures reveal that 272 youngsters with disabilities from fetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England over the past 12 months, with experts warning the actual number could be much higher. Research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical issues due to alcohol exposure in the womb, equating to about 7,500 annually. The condition is described as an enormous, under-diagnosed problem, with children born with the syndrome not getting better. A case example is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who needs help dressing, has no sense of danger, and will never live independently. Other medical issues linked to alcohol during pregnancy include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women not to drink, recommending a maximum of two units no more than twice a week, but some believe this guidance should change to advise against drinking entirely during pregnancy.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew Mckerry, was jailed after his attempt to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham, was foiled. The masked 31-year-old demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty but was tackled by shop owner Sab Dhillon, sending shelves and produce tumbling. During the struggle, Dhillon's wife Sam hit Mckerry twice with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him while her husband revealed his face to the cameras. The police later arrived and arrested Mckerry, who had previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years. Mckerry, known as "boomerang boy" or "homing pigeon boy," had a history of crime, including shoplifting at age 12, being arrested 80 times by 15, and convictions for various offenses.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with gang rape following an alleged sexual assault at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks. They must stay in Nova Scotia until tried, with bail conditions requiring them to live on a Canadian naval base, surrender their passports, and continue working for the Royal Navy while drawing their current pay. The accused, who include Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley, appeared in court and were ordered not to contact the victim or six witnesses, as well as not to leave the province or apply for new passports. The alleged incident occurred after they returned from a hockey game, and they face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

A mother, Valerie Jackson, was shocked when a stranger reported her to police for child abuse, mistaking her son Rj's rare skin disease, Netherton's syndrome, for signs of abuse. Rj, one of just 70 people worldwide with the condition, has skin that appears red, inflamed, and scaly. Valerie has to regularly cover him in creams to prevent his skin from drying out. While out shopping, she was surrounded by armed police after a member of the public called officers. Rj's condition, a rare congenital skin disease, makes his skin red and scaly, and he has faced taunts and being treated as an outcast. Valerie and her husband have to manage Rj's symptoms, but they and their son face cruel taunts from bullies, mostly adults.

Protein World's controversial posters featuring a bikini-clad model, "Are You Beach Body Ready?" on the London Underground, have been removed by Transport for London (TFL) after the three-week advertising period ended. The campaign caused backlash, with feminists, body image campaigners, and bloggers objecting to the perceived promotion of an unhealthy body image, leading to a change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority. TFL confirmed the posters were being taken down and would consider future similar requests. The company defended the campaign on social media and during an interview on Good Morning Britain, with their head of global marketing stating it was targeted at health-conscious individuals. Despite the controversy, Protein World's boss, Richard Staveley, insisted it was a "fantastic campaign" and they won't change their advertising methods. The ASA is assessing complaints to see if there are grounds for further action.

Rail firms faced criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87 per cent just ten days after the general election, despite main party leaders pledging to freeze prices. The Prime Minister, David Cameron, requested First Great Western to urgently review its decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his Witney constituency. Passengers from Charlbury, near his constituency home, will see an increase from £33.30 to £62.40 for an off-peak return to London. The planned changes have angered Cameron's constituents, prompting his personal intervention. Train companies have three annual windows to increase unregulated fares, and First Great Western claims the change is to align the North Cotswolds route with other services. Other sharp price hikes include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton and an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool. Virgin also announced fare increases, defending that most affected "Virgin trains-only fares" are at least 20 per cent cheaper than rival firms' tickets.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown at his front door when he confronted thugs who were pelting his home in Oldham with stones. The attack occurred as he and his new wife, Elaine, were in their front room writing thank you cards for wedding gifts, just three weeks after their marriage. Despite undergoing emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight, leaving him blind in one eye. Police are investigating but have stated there appears to be no motive, suggesting it could be yobs "messing around." The couple, who feel targeted and unsafe, are considering moving away from the neighborhood.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract extension, rewarded for his successful return from injury. Poynton, 25, missed the entire 2014 campaign due to leg injuries from a road accident that resulted in his father Keith's death last April. After undergoing an ankle operation, he made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. He will be available for the start of the season and is now committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing delight at his return and hoping the new contract gives him confidence to express himself this summer.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been given the all clear by doctors after battling the disease for a year. His ninja turtle mask helped him feel stronger during radiotherapy, and his bravery caught the attention of hospital staff. Harley underwent intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumour, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. After his story made headlines, he received presents from the children's TV channel Nickelodeon. Now cancer-free, he will have regular check-ups and his family is overjoyed, hoping he will soon return to school full time.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future, emphasizing that Grealish must continue to perform well for the club before making a decision. Grealish is currently at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England for his international allegiance. Sherwood believes it is up to Grealish to decide where he wants to go, similar to his experience with Nabil Bentaleb. Grealish's dad, Kevin, agrees with this advice, noting that Grealish needs to keep doing well at the club level first. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season, with the decision being difficult and entirely up to him.

Private jet travelers face varying landing fees at airports, with some hubs charging surprisingly high fees. These fees offer insight into popular transport hubs for the wealthy, including Salzburg in Austria and Darwin in Australia. Owning a private jet is a luxury for the wealthy, with landing charges sometimes reaching thousands. The industry is growing, with significant market values in the US and Europe. Busy weekends for private jets often coincide with major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, is noted as the most expensive for landing fees, followed by Narita International Airport and Kansai International Airport in Osaka. Other high-fee airports include Dublin, Bristol in the UK, Toronto Pearson in Canada, and La Guardia in New York. Surprisingly, the three most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda being the highest.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her dog Cooper to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream with his pal Daisy. While Daisy takes a few ladylike licks, Cooper gobbles the rest of the cone in one bite, as he always eats quickly. Gallegos ensures Daisy gets her fill first before offering the meal. The video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched more than seven million times. Some viewers find the scene cute and hilarious, while others criticize Gallegos for feeding the creamy treat. She insists it's fine, noting Cooper is an athlete in amazing health and had an ice cream about once a week. Additionally, another video shows the duo visiting Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," with Cooper taking the whole cup to demolish the contents, which is just whip cream in a cup.

Gary Locke, the Kilmarnock interim manager, has been given the role on a permanent basis after signing a three-year deal. He previously joined the club as assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer and took control of the team when Johnston quit at the start of February. Locke has lost just once in seven games since taking over at Rugby Park.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to essential oils he wears to help him stay calm and focused. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, are said to smell and be a distraction to other children. Kemp claims her son has been using them all year, but a teacher's aide complained. She received a letter from the local school board stating the oils had created a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat, Kemp insists on continuing to use the oils, believing they have a positive impact. However, the Lake County school district later said they would not suspend Logan, referring to it as a health issue. The family uses Doterra oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons was obliterated by flames, with smoke pouring over Westhampton Beach as a fire spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed. The cause of the blaze is unknown, but it was so intense it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire teams were deployed, using cranes to approach the fire, but could not get inside any of the summer homes. The fire was visible from three miles away, and residents described flames coming out of every window. The building manager, who lived and worked in the Sandpiper complex, lost everything, and a witness reported seeing flames from about three miles away. The fire is being investigated, with claims it started near a car parked by the complex.

The Queen, approaching her 89th birthday, was seen enjoying a ride in the spring sunshine on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She prefers a silk scarf over a riding helmet, as she has never worn one and is reluctant to do so for the sake of her hair. Her Majesty has a long-standing love for horses, beginning with her first Shetland pony, Peggy, at age four. Recently, she has ridden less due to a niggling knee injury. The Queen also breeds fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud, with these ponies being one of the oldest equine breeds, historically used by various groups like the Romans and Vikings.

An argument between two Brisbane neighbours over noise levels turned tragic, resulting in one man's death and another charged with manslaughter. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old shift worker Phillip Pama during a row in front of their homes. Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise in his yard, prompting Pama, who was sleeping for a 3 am shift, to confront him. Pama's defence lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for getting drunk and playing loud music, and the situation escalated when Pama grabbed his neighbour by the hand and hit out "blindly." Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene, and Pama was granted conditional bail, ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to the local police station twice a week. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

A jilted 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, wanted to hire a hitman to torture and murder 15-year-old Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship. She asked a friend to find someone willing to do this in exchange for 100,000 rubles (£1,400). Police set up a sting operation, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman during a meeting in Shatura, near Moscow. A secret camera filmed Simonova, who had showered the pupil with gifts and money before he dumped her, saying she wanted the boy to slowly bleed to death and suffer unbearable pain. She specified breaking his arms and legs, attacking his kidneys, and leaving his face untouched. After handing over some expense money to the "killer," she was arrested by armed police in her car and faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya, who ended the relationship for a classmate, expressed relief and hoped the guards would "throw away the key" for Simonova's prison cell.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, talks to God every day but never discusses football or the game with his wife. He believes in separating his professional and family life, praying for things in his personal life and not about Chelsea. Despite his competitive persona, he claims to be a good person, a good family person, and a good friend, making mistakes in his professional area but emphasizing that a person is more than just their professional life.

For the first time in eight years, TV legend Bob Barker returned to "The Price is Right," taking charge of the proceedings on the April 1 edition instead of host Drew Carey. Barker, who had hosted the game show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, looked spry at 91 and handled the first price-guessing game, the classic "Lucky Seven," before turning hosting duties over to Carey. Despite being away from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker didn't seem to miss a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was taken into custody on the 3200 block of D Street SE by the Metropolitan Police and charged with a felony for attempted burglary and destruction of property. The agency revoked his security clearance and put him on leave following the arrest. Baldwin is posted to the foreign missions branch, which deals with U.S. diplomatic activities. His arrest comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave due to accused misconduct, with the homeland security department's inspector general investigating both cases. These incidents are the latest challenges for the agency responsible for protecting the president and his family.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away in Lahore's safari park. Armed only with a camera, he crept up to within 10 feet of the lion before lying on the ground. The clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion to his presence, forcing Saeed to retreat rapidly. He described the experience, saying the lion treated him like prey and that the story finished in a few seconds as the lion aggressively jumped towards him, allowing him to just about scramble into his car. Saeed mentioned laughing at the time but doubts he could do it again, calling it a pretty close encounter.

New York City police have released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unnamed woman, hoping to identify her after she died nearly a month ago on a Brooklyn street. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Paramedics could not revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. She had no identification but sported a distinctive heart tattoo with the name "Monique" on her right leg. Investigators are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death and are asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK and not being able to afford property. They spent a year and a half on this labor of love, creating a solar-powered, two-bedroom wood and steel home. Now, they live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand, surrounded by nature, with a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and other comforts. The home is powered mostly by solar panels, with a first power bill of just $25, and water comes from a nearby spring. The project cost them about $25,000, and they even plan to build another one someday.

Children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests than those who don't, according to researchers. Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads over an academic year significantly outscored peers in classes without iPads or where each student had their own device, with shared iPad students scoring around 30 points higher. The findings suggest that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, made the difference. Blackwell worked with 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district and recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

A piglet born with its back legs missing has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on just two feet, mastering the art of balancing on its front trotters. The heartwarming clip shows the young animal taking unsteady steps, wobbling about with its snout to the ground, foraging for food, and remarkably regaining balance when close to tipping over. It happily mixes with its litter, which have all been born with a full complement of legs. The piglet, belonging to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai city in Sichuan province, has captured the hearts of thousands since a video went online, with villagers flocking to see the curious animal. Notably, it is not the first animal in China to win plaudits for walking on two legs, as a rabbit at Liuzhou zoo also became a star attraction for the same reason.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was hit by the car of Francesco Dracone during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center, received stitches for a cut on his leg, and was released. Dracone had come in on lap 25 for tires and fuel and did not finish the race, ending up 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, smashed his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, head into concrete paving 11 times and then shot her in the face five times. He confessed to the brutal act out of jealousy over men looking at her. The incident occurred in their apartment's garden in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, after he yelled at her, calling her a "slut." Horrified neighbor Lelio Maya Puga heard the argument and gunshots. After shooting his wife, who went by the stage name Amanda Bueno, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was picked up by police after crashing it. In his car, police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest. He now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author, opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, revealing she came close to taking her own life due to anxiety, which made her believe she couldn't see the point of continuing. She described feeling isolated, with a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family contributing to her belief that her life wasn't worth living. Now, she has found some peace and sees depression and anxiety as intrinsically linked, emphasizing the need to acknowledge this connection to tackle the increasing rates affecting Australian women. Wilson also mentioned that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," with the Beyond Blue report indicating one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven-months pregnant, beat her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her getting high on heroin in her bathroom. She was charged with second-degree assault for striking the ex-girlfriend in the head and arm. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law allows physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney mentioned the ex-girlfriend was jealous and had harassed Curtin, stolen from her, and plotted to drag the boyfriend back into addiction. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma the pit bull, filmed at home in California, was being fed treats when her owner tried to trick her by adding a broccoli spear. The dog immediately showed a look of disgust, chomped on the vegetable, and then spit it out on the floor. The hope is that the two children she lives with won't follow her lead and instead learn to love their greens. Other videos show Gemma enjoying sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC has apologised after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. This occurred when anyone tried to access the bank's page for the young entrepreneur awards, which was later shut down. The porn site took over the address after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the organisers allowed its registration on hsbc.com.hk to retire. As a result, the website's URL, which usually connects to a third-party website, transferred visitors to the porn business instead. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website after realising the mistake, denied any association with the external site, and offered an apology to the public. The bank also insisted its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home in Clinton, trapping him and his nine-year-old sister, Aaliyah, in a second-floor bedroom. During the 11-minute call, he stayed calm, provided instructions to firefighters, soothed his sister, and told the dispatcher about their situation. Firefighters rescued the siblings by entering the room and breaking a window, with Marcus being handed out the window to another rescuer. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while the three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar Hospital.

Amazing pictures of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast have emerged, with images taken in Jervis Bay, the south coast of NSW, showing a neon glow illuminating a popular beach. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the scene as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the glow is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton, which blossoms in the spring and autumn and in 90 per cent of occasions occurs due to natural causes.

New tests that pinpoint genetic markers in breast cancer tumors can determine their aggressiveness, potentially sparing patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened in a lab, allowing women to know within days if they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some, the test can show a risk as low as five per cent, which is as good as or better than the odds for those undergoing chemotherapy. If a test like Endopredict shows a low score, patients can choose not to have chemotherapy. Most of these tests are available privately at about £2,500, with hopes they may soon be accessible on the NHS. Experts believe this helps patients make informed choices, as opposed to routinely giving chemotherapy. An example is Becca Cornford, who, after testing, learned her chances of recurrence were just five per cent, and chemotherapy could not offer much better odds.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with one ship, HMS Ocean, having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency medevacs over nine years. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious, and eighteen other ships had emergency evacuations. A strict 'no touching' rule is in place at sea, suggesting women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant, with strict military rules banning mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone, spotted by a staff member, had a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle with the radioactive substance. This discovery occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant. Chief cabinet secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed worries about future terrorism attempts at the Olympics and G7 summit using drones, emphasizing the need to review drone operations and counter threats. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports but lacks such restrictions for most of Tokyo, including the prime minister's residence.

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work on the back of his motorbike every day. He does this because he is scared she will get lost if left at home, especially after his father passed away and there is no one else to look after her. Lu ties a sash around both their waists to ensure she does not fall off and rides slowly to make sure she feels safe, allowing them to chat along the way. At work, he checks up on his mother, who has been given her own room by his employer, a bank, to ensure she has not wandered off. Lu feels a duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to caring for her children, and he said that seeing her makes him feel relaxed, as he is afraid she might have wandered away otherwise.

More Americans are drinking heavily and engaging in binge-drinking, with heavy drinking among Americans rising 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, largely due to increasing rates among women. The study, by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, found that the increases are driven by women's drinking habits as social norms change, with women's binge drinking rates rising more significantly than men's. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, noting that despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged. Public health experts attribute the rise to cultural and economic factors, including changed social norms, the influx of wealthy professionals in cities, and weakened alcohol control policies.

UN officials warn that doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily, as the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary. They state that caesareans can lead to infections, complications, disability, or even death, and divert money away from other patients' needs. In England, just over a quarter of women giving birth have a caesarean, with the rate more than doubling since the early 1990s, including a growing number opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The World Health Organisation suggests the ideal rate should be between 10 per cent and 15 per cent. The WHO statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow the procedure even without medical justification, such as for women very anxious about childbirth.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, has been arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living inside for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. She was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17 at the court street property in Edgartown, where she claimed to own the house before fleeing when police were called. Filkins was later arrested after attempting to get back into the home. She has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home, including a lamp and a painting, to return them to the Edgartown police department.

A lost iPhone was reunited with its owner, Bella Crooke from Melbourne, after police posted a series of bizarre photos on her Facebook page to track her down. The phone was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border, and officers, realizing it was unlocked, used it to post selfies and photos in various locations around the station. They also shared puns and messages, such as saying the phone was in a holding "cell" and would be fully "charged" when picked up. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone without giving her name, as officers recognized her from the Facebook page. The police were even texting her friends back with the same humor, and Bella expressed gratitude for their good sense of humor and for getting her phone back.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was mauled to death after getting caught up in a fight between two adult hippos. The helpless calf was thrown into the air and then dragged along the surface of the water in the Isimangaliso wetland park, with its mother watching in horror. The mother had stayed with her herd, possibly believing it safer to stay out of harm's way, but her decision proved fatal when one of the brawling adults grabbed the calf between its jaws. The baby stood no chance against the two adults as they fought in the muddy waters, and it died of its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, one of the most expensive areas in Britain, is on the market for £575,000 but has just three years left on the lease. The cost would work out at £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, around the going rate for renting a similar flat in the area. The property, described as unmodernised and in need of renovation, could be worth upwards of £6 million if a buyer decides to extend the lease. It is one of two maisonettes being sold with short leases, and the current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust. A developer or someone might use it as a rental for three years and then give it back to the freeholder, with a warning that there will be a massive premium to pay to extend the lease.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The issue, which began in the early evening on the east coast and late afternoon on the west coast, prevented staff from accepting credit cards or ringing up sales, though some locations accepted cash. Many Starbucks locations closed their doors to avoid giving away free products during the shutdown. The company announced the outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and that stores are expected to return to "business as usual" Saturday. The tech snafu occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of west Wales, with locations in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire being used to radicalize Muslims, according to an officer from the Wales extremism and counter terrorism unit. Detective Constable Gareth Jones mentioned that those involved take part in seemingly ordinary community activities but have an ulterior motive, stressing that terrorism issues are not confined to large cities. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales date back to 1998, and there have been instances like the 7/7 bombers being photographed in north Wales and a gang plotting terror attacks. Additionally, Michael Adebowale, convicted in the murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at an institute linked to Iraqi clerics. Community intelligence is highlighted as vital for authorities to address these concerns.

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, feared to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, it was confirmed as an Omura's whale through DNA profiling. The find is considered highly significant for whale scientists, as very little is known about the species, which was first described in scientific journals in 2003 and is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried, with the skeleton to be recovered for further investigation and possible public display.

Cheryl Rios, a female businesswoman, argues that Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president due to hormones potentially making her irrational and starting unnecessary wars, reflecting a belief that women shouldn't be in such a position. However, the passage suggests that if hormones are a concern, male candidates should be more worrying, as studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The text also highlights a broader issue of gender bias in the workplace, which limits women's potential and makes a female candidate's road to the presidency steeper. It emphasizes that equality benefits everyone, with evidence showing advantages for the bottom line, families, and teams. Despite Rios's view, the article points out that bias against women is real and pervasive, and it's not just a problem for Democrats but for everyone.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is selling his collection of antiques in a £100,000 auction to downsize his home. The auction includes over 200 items collected over his career, such as a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of him holding the bow. Other items feature paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and dozens of books, some from the 17th century. The sale, set to take place on Saturday, is being handled by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire. Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and playing Winston Churchill, expressed sadness at parting with his collection but hopes those who acquire his items will find as much joy as he did.

Michael Scott Shemansky is on the run after being named a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. Authorities came to his attention when he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was discovered. An initial investigation determined there was foul play, and neighbors believe the stress of divorce proceedings may have pushed Shemansky over the edge, with his mother possibly preventing him from making the meeting with his son. He is already on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed for an attempted suicide. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not yet confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication, and his estranged wife is reportedly preparing to protect herself if he arrives at her home.

Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations Council, who bypassed the usual bidding process, viewing it as a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha.
