The IAAF president, Lamine Diack, highlighted that this choice enables taking advantage of a unique opportunity with public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public joining forces. The 2007 world championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process.

An aspiring model, Leonie Granger, set a honey trap to lure professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death in a bid to steal his winnings, resulting in her being jailed for 16 years after being found guilty of manslaughter. Granger targeted Hassan after seeing him at a casino, befriending him and using his generosity. She then left his flat unlocked so her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, could enter, tie up Hassan, and kick him to death while ransacking his home. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by the judge, with Granger and the co-defendants also convicted of robbing Hassan and conspiracy to falsely imprison him. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and received life sentences with a minimum term of 36 years.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling during the second half of the season, showing a significant dip in form from his earlier performance that seemed to set him up to break the Barclays Premier League assist record. His poor form was evident in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland, where he was one of the worst players on the pitch. Despite a brilliant start to the season, Fabregas has seen his contributions decrease as the season progresses, with his stats showing a downward trend. This has raised questions about his durability, and his current form might prevent him from surpassing Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists. However, there is still potential for a late-season resurgence, which could be crucial for Chelsea's Premier League title charge, as Jose Mourinho looks to guide the team to success.

West Ham is discussing a deal for Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a skilful 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United, after he impressed on trial with the club's academy. Beckford has also received offers from clubs in Belgium and is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has revealed that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, making it the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League to help fill the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on Mike Lane, a huntsman and joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, despite evidence pointing to the identity of a suspected attacker. Lane was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, resulting in him being hospitalized with concussion, broken teeth, and a swollen face, along with suffering memory loss. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including some names of saboteurs and car registration numbers, were given to Wiltshire Police, but they issued the suspect's photograph without identifying him. The police confirmed shelving inquiries due to insufficient evidence, which has dismayed hunt supporters and led to Lane feeling let down and losing trust in the police. The case has been recorded as undetected, with the possibility of being re-opened if other evidence comes to light.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece of al Qaeda, was killed in January in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation. He was not specifically targeted but was one of al Qaeda's most prominent members, having risen through the ranks in the tribal areas of Pakistan to become its chief official English-language propagandist. Gadahn, who converted to Islam and left the United States for Pakistan, appeared in al Qaeda videos urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests and criticizing U.S. presidents. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. His final video, posted in September 2014, called for Muslims to work to overthrow governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan.

A five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo has become a rising basketball superstar in China after a viral video showcased his dazzling skills, including scoring a succession of hoops and dribbling two basketballs. His incredible abilities have won him legions of fans, with netizens stunned by his potential and leaving thousands of comments. Some even question if it's special effects or express feelings of shame in comparison to the kid's talents.

Tom O'carroll, a leading member of the notorious Paedophile Information Exchange, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. The organization, set up after the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation, wanting MPs to establish a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson inquiry. O'carroll, who was on the National Council for Civil Liberties' gay rights sub-committee and was jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals, wrote a blog confirming his attendance at the meeting chaired by comedian John Cleese. The news of O'carroll backing Hacked Off will be an embarrassment to the group.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall, showcasing a capsule collection of ten unisex clothing pieces designed to be worn in 20 ways. The minimalist, androgynous designs were presented against a backdrop of the ocean, with guests enjoying nibbles and drinks while taking in the show.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent his Friday at a safari park in northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. They enjoyed posing and feeding a rare white tiger, as well as interacting with giraffes and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Earlier this week, Khan ended speculation about his next opponent by announcing a fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, despite pressure to take on British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian teenager who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis, had his name on an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His family and Almagor, an organization for terror victims in Israel, objected to his inclusion, with the latter describing his death as a rogue attack and not recognizing him as a terror victim. Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove his name from the memorial wall, and it has already been taken off the organization's website.

A California-based YouTube user named Lionel Hutz filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden to get some rest. The footage shows the cat licking its fur before the boy plonks himself on top. After a brief moment, the cat gets up and moves to another spot, with the boy following and repeating the action. Eventually, the cat decides it's had enough of being used as a pillow and wanders off indoors. Later, the duo makes up, and the boy is seen feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, with witness Robert Kushner losing his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his years selling marijuana. Kushner, one of more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government, told jurors that some undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. He had passed a background check when hired to coach basketball in 2010 and testified that the 2007 charges were expunged as part of a probationary sentence. On cross-examination, he acknowledged being arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, as well as pleading guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Lawyers for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering claim the government case is based on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province, which produces paraxylene (PX), resulted in six people being hurt and sparked a huge fire. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, with five injured by broken glass and sent to the hospital. Over 600 firefighters were dispatched, and the fire is now under control. Residents near the plant in Zhangzhou city heard the explosion and posted photos of the fire on Weibo. The plant, previously slated for Xiamen, was relocated to its current location after provoking backlash in 2007 due to pollution concerns. It had another explosion in July 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. The construction of PX plants has sparked protests in several cities, occasionally turning violent, despite demonstrations being illegal in China.

Jack Grealish has a message for Premier League referees, stating that he won't listen to their advice to pull his socks up, as it's a superstition he's maintained all his life. He is renowned for wearing his socks low, just above the roll of his shinpads, and uses children's size shinpads, which might not be immediately noticeable. Despite a few referees trying to tell him otherwise, Grealish insists on keeping it that way, hoping not to have a kick on his shin. His first league start for Aston Villa came in a pulsating 3-3 draw against QPR, and he was pleased to have finally made his Premier League start, even if he wasn't happy about how the game ended. Grealish expressed that it was a tough game in a big relegation scrap but appreciated the gaffer's faith in him, aiming to get more starts before the season's end.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive, not reacting to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow people. A source confirmed her neurological state has been the same for nearly three months, with a tracheostomy in her throat. Bobby Brown claimed his daughter is awake and watching him, while an attorney for the family stated her condition has improved, though the kind of life she will lead remains uncertain. Doctors indicate she will have a long life, embarking on a rehabilitation process, with the quality of her life not known for years.

Russia is on the brink of making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to beat Germany's Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova overcame Lisicki in a close match, 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova's earlier straight-sets victory over Julia Goerges. Both players faced serve issues, with Pavlyuchenkova having 13 double faults and Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proving crucial. The result means Russia needs one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, already reeling from last week's wild weather, are being warned to brace for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate an east coast low, similar to the one that lashed the state's east coast, could bring heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs still to be completed from the previous week's requests. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills highlighted particular worry about the effect on the hard-hit Hunter region, urging the community to prepare themselves, their homes, and families to prevent further loss. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott mentioned a trough of low pressure forming along the coast, with heavy rain likely in the far northern parts of the state, but not over Sydney. The Bureau of Meteorology noted early indications of intense rainfall and strong winds affecting coastal areas in the state's northeast, with rain increasing this week and peaking between Thursday and Saturday.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's video for "La Vida Loca," denied claims that she tried to take her own life. She explained to her followers that she was treated in hospital after collapsing due to low blood pressure, not from a suicide attempt. Italian media had reported that she was found by her mother in her Milan apartment, with her boyfriend suggesting it was true. However, Moric stated it was a domestic accident where she fell, banging her head and hurting herself. She also mentioned that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time. Moric reassured fans that she was well, recovering at home, and only needed rest, dismissing the suicide reports as incorrect.

As Kate and William prepare for the arrival of their second child, the British public are hoping they will choose a traditional name, with Diana being the favorite option for a girl, as revealed by a YouGov survey for the Sunday Times. Twelve percent of people questioned thought the child should be named after William's mother, Diana, the late princess of Wales. Alice and Charlotte followed in preference, with nine percent each. If the child is a boy, James is the top choice at 13 percent, followed by Alexander. Many people are hoping for a girl, with a quarter of the 2,200 polled wanting the duke and duchess of Cambridge to have a female baby. The choices were also echoed on social media, with users expressing delight at the possibility of the baby being named after William's mother. Additionally, the majority of Brits are supporting William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job, with 68 percent giving it a thumbs up.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding dozens, including an Afghan lawmaker, according to police. The attack occurred as the protesters were heading to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility, and no other organization has claimed it.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer, which was a three-year extension dependent on him playing 60 per cent of matches. His representative, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that negotiations are over, as the club presented this as their final offer. Alves has been unable to agree on a new deal with the Catalan club, despite having seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice.

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Argentinian giants Boca Juniors. Osvaldo, who has become an instant hit at his current side with three goals in six games, believes the duo would be a good fit for Boca, saying the fans would love to have them line up on the La Bombonera pitch. He mentions that they have a south-American style and their abilities would make the Bombonera go crazy for players like them.

Lewis Ferguson, an amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from the favorite Merrion Square at Wincanton, which has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Despite the dramatic fall, he was back riding out and only had a cut on his nose to show for the ordeal. Ferguson described the incident as a blur and mentioned that other jockeys watched with him, looking away in horror. He felt lucky, received some abuse from the lads, and picked up a few hundred Twitter followers, considering it all good banter. He even joked about possibly pursuing a gymnastics career after racing, given the somersaults.

James Haskell showed off his inner Iron Man in a serious-looking Instagram post as the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie was released, with the premiere happening at Westfield London shopping centre. The London Wasps captain, who returned to the club where he started his career for the 2012 season, posted the image dressed as Iron Man, accompanied by a message about the movie. Haskell had previously moved to Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and the Highlanders in New Zealand after leaving Wasps in 2009, but he came back to England in 2012. Since returning, he has surpassed the 100 appearances mark for Wasps and is a significant part of the England squad with 57 caps to-date.

The wide leg trouser is a trend gaining attention, appearing at the forefront of ss15 trends and offering an alternative to the long-reigning skinny jean. It can come as a welcome relief, with something effortless about it that appeals. While it can be intimidating, especially for shorter individuals, the key to pulling it off is in the shoe, keeping heels high and the top half simple to elongate the leg. Denim is highlighted as the easiest way to nail the trend, with Gucci revisiting the seventies with flared jeans and Topshop offering a high street version in the Miller jean. Celine and Stella McCartney also showcased the look, with Celine presenting colorful billowing bottoms and Stella having tried the trend seven years ago. A wide billowing trouser silhouette is set to update wardrobes this season.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students who signed a petition asking the school not to show it as part of UMIX, a series of social events. Some students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq war reflected negatively on the Middle East and people from that region. There was a backlash to the decision to yank the movie, and a counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider. E. Royster Harper, the university's vice president for student life, stated that canceling the movie was a mistake, emphasizing the university's value on freedom of expression and students' right to make their own choices. UMIX will also offer a screening of "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper."

A quokka was the victim of a cruel act by two French tourists who allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to make contact with the animal on Rottnest Island off Perth in Western Australia on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, and both were evicted from the island. They have each been charged with animal cruelty and will appear in court on April 17.

Alice B Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s who performed at New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar, had never seen any of her motion pictures or photographs, which had all been lost over the years. With help from filmmakers, she went back in time by watching a video of "soundies" put together by Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers, which showed her dancing. The experience delighted her, and she called it "just fabulous."

Washing one's own car is becoming less common in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never done it and three-quarters of women never washing their cars, often opting for local forecourt car washes. A study by OSV found that only 12 per cent of those who do wash their cars do it regularly. Factors contributing to the decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the size of 4x4 and off-road vehicles. However, Brits are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, with one in four doing it as an excuse to get out of the house. Cars are most likely to be washed weekly in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most often washed by their owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least often.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since arriving at Anfield in 2008, highlighting Gerrard's help in settling in and considering him one of the best players in the world. Skrtel believes Liverpool can overcome the challenge of replacing Gerrard, who is set to feature in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead the team into the final against Arsenal. Should Liverpool win, Gerrard will sign off his Anfield career in the final on his birthday before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but feels the club has potential replacements who can fill his void if given the right support.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole in one on the 130-yard fourth during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, giving the crowd a moment to cheer. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus made his first ace on the hallowed turf of Augusta. However, his achievement was eclipsed by Camilo Villegas, who followed with an ace on the fourth and also managed one on the eighth. Despite Villegas' efforts, he lost out to Kevin Streelman in a play-off.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas as several storms brought reports of twisters, with spotters noting a tornado near Goddard, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities. Nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as the most deadly and dangerous by CNN's severe weather expert. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas, including near Aetna. A possible tornado also touched down in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage, flooding, and a fallen tree. Unusual dark clouds were observed in Leadington, and a Twitter user in Farmington reported baseball-sized hail. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi river valley, Tennessee river valley, and near the southern great lakes.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, who is accused of fatally shooting Eric Harris instead of subduing him with a taser, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter. The judge allowed Bates to go to the Bahamas for a family vacation, which the Harris family criticized as showing apathy. Bates claims the shooting was accidental and has apologized, with his preliminary hearing set for July 2. The family's lawyer alleges that Bates wasn't qualified for the force and received preferential treatment due to donations and being a friend of the sheriff, allegations denied by the sheriff's office. Some training documents were released by a lawyer, asserting Bates had proper law enforcement training.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 and has revealed a new tiger face tattoo on his stomach, stating that if you see the tiger, it's too late, and you're food. McGregor, who already has a gorilla eating a heart tattoo on his chest, claims Aldo lacks the same motivation as him to want the belt, asserting that Aldo doesn't want to be near him or have this fight the way McGregor does. The pair have a fractious relationship, and McGregor believes he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time.

Tony Abbott, the Australian prime minister, drew criticism after skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, with anti-drinking campaigners claiming he was glorifying binge drinking and associating being a man with drinking booze. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, called it problematic, as it sets up a culture where drinking is about how quickly and how much you can consume rather than socializing with friends. Critics argue he should be setting an example that you don't have to drink heavily to be a 'true blue aussie bloke.' Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating there was 'nothing wrong' with his antics.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County, up from 106 last week. This rise is linked to an outbreak among intravenous drug users primarily using the painkiller Opana. Gov. Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, and health officials expect case numbers to rise as more people are tested. The program's future and legislation allowing needle-exchange programs in other counties are uncertain, with Pence opposing such exchanges as anti-drug policy. There is a bill to allow needle-exchange programs in counties with high hepatitis C rates, but concerns about promoting drug use and funding sustainability remain.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, sit a test quizzing her about his favorite football club. She scored an impressive 43.5 out of 50, with the boyfriend commenting that he would not be dumping her. The test, resembling a school exam, included multiple choice questions, tables to complete, and sections asking for explanations in her own words. Saskia posted the test on her Twitter account, showing she did not know whether to laugh or cry. She struggled to name all 11 players of the starting squad and got confused on player positions, but her creative answers, like explaining why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard, earned her some points. The boyfriend drew an angry face when she got a question wrong, showing he meant business. Despite this, he was impressed with the end result, grading her an "A" and rewarding her by not ending their relationship. The post received mixed reactions, with some hailing the boyfriend as a legend and others feeling he took things too far.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked for the DEA as an undercover operative for 27 years in exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship. After fleeing Colombia due to a confrontation with his boss, he provided information about former bosses and associates, becoming one of the DEA's strongest assets and helping carry out undercover stings. Now retired and facing deportation, Toro claims that if sent back to Colombia, he would be dead within the first four hours. The DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he went public with his plight, leaving him living in the U.S. illegally. His fears are reasonable, as his work aided in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Toro remains in limbo, trying to get a green card or passport, and cannot collect social security benefits until securing one of those documents.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district. She is now fighting for her life in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with 70 per cent burns. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. The accused men have been arrested. This case comes amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the banning of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of an Indian student, Jyoti Singh, in Delhi. Recent attacks have led to street protests calling for more protection for women.

Louis van Gaal, Manchester United's manager, dreams of beating Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford but will have to do so without Robin van Persie, as he has been ruled out despite being fit, not being fit enough for Van Gaal. Van Gaal also ruled out a potential return for Luke Shaw, considering him not yet at the standard of match fitness required. The manager acknowledges that City will provide a stern challenge and plays down the idea of being motivated by revenge after losing the away fixture earlier. Van Gaal is looking forward to the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford and aims to take all three points to move towards finishing as high as second or third, avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Barclays Premier League clash at the Emirates Stadium. Supporters from both clubs expressed being 'disgusted' at the increasing costs, with the protest occurring after the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Tickets at the sold-out Emirates started from £64 for the 12.45pm kick-off, and protesters aimed to raise awareness of the struggles fans face. Banners inside and outside the ground, including one reading '£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket,' highlighted their concerns. Organizers, such as Kelvin Meadows of Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Roy Bentham of Spirit of Shankly, called the prices 'extortionate' and sought tangible reductions in line with what working-class people earn. The event saw fans from both sides uniting, putting aside old rivalries, and further protests were expected after full-time at the Emirates.

A newborn baby, Star Reader, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent, shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant became necessary for her survival. Neither of her parents was a suitable match, but her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, who is the twin sister of Star's mother, offered part of her liver. Shanell was tested and found to be the best candidate, and she gave up part of her organ without hesitation. Star underwent the transplant in November, spent six weeks in hospital, and has since made a good recovery, now living with the chance to have a normal life, thanks to her aunt's selfless act.

Chelsea players, including Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake, participated in Audi's football challenge, taking on team-mates Loic Remy and Willian. The challenge involved various tasks, such as firing balls into the boot of a car and shooting from long range to sink footballs through the top of a convertible Audi. Hazard and Ake initially secured points, winning a head-to-head challenge and a makeshift tennis court round with the net replaced by an Audi R8 V10 plus. However, Remy and Willian redeemed themselves in the final game, producing a shock win. During this, Willian smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audis with a long-range effort, but it seems he won't have to pay for the damage.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, caused a highway crash that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated he wasn't suicidal, despite prosecutors saying he had told investigators he was trying to kill himself when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph into an oncoming SUV. The crash occurred on December 7, 2013, and Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus's death. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit. His attorneys claimed he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, effects of a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

A woman, Lacey Spears, was convicted of killing her five-year-old son by poisoning him with salt and sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. Her ex, the boy's father Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, hoping she would die in prison and showing frustration at her lack of emotion during sentencing. Prosecutors claimed Spears made her son ill for attention, loading his feeding tube with a lethal amount of salt while keeping on blogging. The judge noted her mental illness and the crime's cruelty, while her lawyer requested a minimum sentence, calling her a hardworking mother who gave unconditional love. Prosecutors blamed Spears for her son's short and tormented life, and she plans to appeal the verdict, claiming innocence and blaming the hospital for negligence.

An improved influenza vaccination is arriving in Australia, a month later than expected, to include protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States. The decision to modify the vaccine was triggered by the previous vaccine not being a good match to fight these strains. High-risk groups, such as the very young and old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, emphasize that the modified vaccine is worth waiting for and should be a good match for circulating strains, aiming to prevent more deaths. Dr. Hampson also encourages people to book their flu shots now, even if not in high-risk groups, to protect those around them.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are on the defensive due to an unflattering critique in National Geographic magazine and looming budget cuts that could threaten the management of the historic site. Illinois faces a financial crisis, with Gov. Bruce Rauner proposing to eliminate the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb. The timing is awkward as the state commemorates the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. The tomb, described as a disappointment and having all the historical character of an office lobby, has seen reduced hours and fewer staff since funding cuts. Supporters, like Pam Vanalstine of the Lincoln Monument Association, express concern about further cuts and disagree with the National Geographic portrayal. The tomb has undergone recent repairs and renovations, with the state working on additional projects. Designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, it has been reconstructed for public access to the interior burial chamber.

Nineties style is currently popular, with items like chokers, berry-coloured lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts being trendy. However, the potential comeback of JNCO's wideleg 'rave' jeans has caused concern. The passage lists several retro nineties and noughties fashion trends that are being reconsidered for revival, including bucket hats, camouflage print, taking fashion to the max with designer prints and double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, coloured sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. These trends were once popular but are now seen as impractical or outdated, with some celebrities like Rihanna, Jourdan Dunn, Kylie Jenner, and others attempting to bring them back.

A busy week for trending stories included four rainbows appearing in the New York area sky, with Amanda Curtis capturing the moment. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is now under a crackdown on vice, leaving families to find new ways to cheer mourners. RDJ grew agitated when asked about his private life by a UK interviewer. The Kardashians inspired a new trend with lip plumping by sucking on a jar to look like Kylie Jenner, using the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge. A 102-year-old, Alice Barker, went back in time with filmmakers' help. A prom-posal referencing bombs was rejected by a school, with the proposer accusing administrators of racism. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast,' drawing social media interest, and Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer. A creative pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombed his son, earning kudos for originality.

Serena Williams is celebrating her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, with a giant cake presented to her after she progressed to the semi-finals by beating Germany’s Sabine Lisicki in three sets. This follows Andy Murray’s 500th win, also marked by a large cake. Williams, the world no 1, will face Romania's Simona Halep for a place in the final after Halep beat Sloane Stephens. Her hopes of meeting sister Venus were dashed by Venus's defeat to Spain’s Carla Suarez Navarro.

Sabeen Mahmud, known for her second floor cafe in Karachi, was a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan, surrounded by books, discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. Her exuberant exercise of free speech made her stand out, and she was shot dead at point-blank range by two gunmen after locking up the cafe. The killing broke hearts for non-violence and progressive values, as she freely expressed her thoughts in a place where many are too afraid. She had just led a discussion on a topic many want silenced, related to the province of Baluchistan, where people have been disappearing. Despite knowing it was a potentially dangerous move and having received past death threats, she invited the debate to her cafe, T2F, a magnet for those seeking secular wisdom. Her death and work have poured out grief and gratefulness on social media and via email, highlighting her role in giving others a room to breathe.

An 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, Mangu Ram, who fled violence after the partition of India, has been denied citizenship rights in Indian Kashmir for decades, unable to own property or vote in state elections. He and thousands like him are now hopeful that their refugee status might change, following the success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in the state. Around 100,000 West Pakistan refugees (WPRs) live in the Jammu region, caught in poverty due to their status and a pre-independence law that grants citizenship only to those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. Successive governments have hesitated to act, fearing disruption of the state's demographic balance. However, with the Bharatiya Janata Party joining a governing coalition, there is hope for normalizing the WPRs' status, as they seek state-subject rights to improve their condition.

Yoshinori Muto, an FC Tokyo forward, is considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer. Club president Naoki Ogane mentioned that an offer, believed to be around £4 million, has been made for the Japan international, with a possible loan to partner club Vitesse Arnhem. Muto is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and realize his potential, stating he wants to think about the switch carefully. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic praised Muto's intelligence and potential, believing he could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto but has not commented extensively, noting that commercial interests play a part in the club's transfer policy.

Australia is praised for dropping the policy of not selecting their best players if they are playing overseas, which leaves England looking old-fashioned and needing to react. The argument is made that Stuart Lancaster should be free to pick his best players regardless of where they ply their trade, as seen with examples like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage, whose performances have improved overseas. The passage emphasizes that the World Cup is about the world's best coming together and that it's wrong to say England is best served by players at English clubs. It supports selecting the best starting XV, especially for a home World Cup, and criticizes the idea of letting the R.F.U. or Premier Rugby dictate who can be picked.

Firechat is an app that allows chatting with friends without needing the web or a mobile signal, using a feature like Apple's multipeer connectivity framework to create wireless mesh networks. Developers at Open Garden have built a device called Greenstone, an egg-shaped gadget acting as a beacon or booster to strengthen these off-the-grid networks, helping messages move more easily. Greenstone is designed to address the limits of how far messages can travel in such networks, around 200ft, by enabling resilient communication in situations like communities, hospitals, or events where connectivity might be an issue. The app has been downloaded over five million times and is useful in places like planes or the underground. Greenstone is still under development, currently working with Firechat at a range of about 20ft, and Open Garden is collaborating with manufacturers to design and sell it.

A burlesque performer, Lillian Bustle, is working to eliminate negativity around the word 'fat' by embracing it as a body-positive self-descriptor, similar to how she uses 'short' and 'wife.' During a TED talk, she discussed how society often equates 'fat' with being ugly, but she insists it doesn't have to be an insult. Lillian highlighted that size discrimination in the workplace has increased and that negative perceptions of bigger bodies start young, with girls wishing to be thinner. However, she finds hope in studies showing that exposure to body diversity leads to greater tolerance and acceptance of different body types. Through burlesque, she aims to expose audiences to a 'fat' body in a positive, glamorous way, challenging societal norms about desirability. Lillian's TED talk, posted on YouTube, has received mostly positive feedback, with some negative comments, but she remains optimistic about the growing body-positivity movement.

Theo Walcott, along with six of his Arsenal colleagues, has been frequently seen sitting on the bench, becoming a familiar sight as he has been overlooked for most of the season. He and his teammates, including Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, were pictured for a photoshoot with runway model Olga Sherer for an official portrait for Paris' oldest fashion house, Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013. Walcott has been named on Arsenal's substitutes' bench for 17 of their 33 Barclays Premier League games and came on for the last six minutes of a goalless draw with Chelsea. He will be hoping to make his first Arsenal start since a win over West Ham when the Gunners face Hull.

Fans of blockbusters like Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas will have a chance to own a piece of Hollywood history as an amazing collection of props and puppets, created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, goes under the hammer at the end of May. The collection from Baker's Cinovation Studio, estimated to be worth $746,100, will be auctioned off at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com on May 29. It includes items from more than 50 productions, with some individual pieces expected to fetch over $40,000. The auction features a variety of items, such as the Alien Edgar bug from Men in Black, the Two Face mask from Batman Forever, and the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas. Additionally, items from other films like An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, and Mighty Joe Young, as well as from Michael Jackson's 1988 Moonwalker film and 1983 thriller music video, will be sold.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his family while skiing. He entered dense woodland, fell over a 164ft drop, and was found by police following footprints in the snow. His family described him as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster who brought laughter and made life full of joy. The tragedy occurred during what they had called the most happy ski holiday in the resort of Flaine. Carwyn's mother, Ceri, desperately tried to find him after he went missing, and it is believed he was heading for the resort, attracted by the ski station he could see below. His body is ready to be repatriated, with the family remaining in the Alps.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to pressures on teenagers to be a "size zero." Her obsession with having the perfect figure led her to hide food, lie about eating, and survive on just one piece of fruit a day. This resulted in her collapsing and being rushed to intensive care, where she was put on a heart machine. Laura spoke about the pressures she felt, including being bullied for her weight and the societal expectation for girls to be thin. After a week on a heart monitor, she received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery. Now, her improved body image and new confidence have helped her make it to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to stay away from size zero stereotypes.

Raheem Sterling was told by Liverpool supporters to remain at the club this summer as he paraded the new home kit at Anfield, presented by US sports brand New Balance in a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal. The message to players was "hold nothing back" during the unveiling, with Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet showing the new strip. Despite Sterling recently rejecting a £100,000-a-week deal and being linked with Arsenal, Liverpool are adamant he will not quit this summer. The event also highlighted the team's focus on the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with players emphasizing the fans' importance as their 12th man.

The University of Manchester researchers have produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, which is the first in a series aiming to provide a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky. This map, created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Dark Energy Survey, allows astronomers to study galaxy formation and the interplay of dark and visible matter. The goal is to eventually map 12.5 per cent of the sky over five years, with the current map covering about 0.4 per cent. The survey uses gravitational lensing to study dark matter's effects, as it cannot be directly observed. The project is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, which will be completed by 2018, mapping dark matter and aiding in understanding the nature of dark energy.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Van Gaal is already familiar with Depay, having included him in his World Cup squad last year as Holland finished third in Brazil. Despite competition from clubs like Paris-Saint Germain, United appears to be in pole position to land the Dutch player, who has been performing well, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season.

Chelsea took a commanding 3-1 lead back to West London after a strong showing in Manchester, with Dominic Solanke scoring late to put a gloss on the scoreline following a Tammy Abraham double that gave them a first-half lead. Key players for Chelsea included Abraham, who scored two volleys, and Fikayo Tomori, who combined well with Jake Clarke-Salter. For Manchester City, Tosin Adarabioyo was a commanding presence in defense, and Brandon Barker created a fine chance for Garcia. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored to level the game, but ultimately, Chelsea's performance saw them take control.

Marco Rubio claimed that people are born with a sexual preference and insisted that state legislators should decide whether to allow gay marriage, rather than it being a constitutional right. He spoke to CBS's Face the Nation after admitting he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he disagreed with the decision. Rubio stated that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman, and that states have always regulated marriage, suggesting any different definition should be decided through a political debate in the state legislature. He also mentioned that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, with no plans or agenda, are cycling to discover different parts of the planet, having quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester. In their open-ended journey, they have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries in 356 days, living on less than three euros each a day. They keep costs down by relying on free accommodation, such as camping, Couchsurfing, and Warmshowers, with food being their only major expense. Their route has taken them from London through various countries in Europe, and they plan to continue into Asia, across the Pacific, with the idea to cycle the length of the American continent.

A couple from Texas, who celebrated their wedding in 2012, claims their photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, wrote hurtful racial slurs, such as "poor n***** party," on the bottom of photo booth snapshots. The couple was not alerted to the photos until many months later when the bride's sister informed them, as she did not want to ruin the wedding day. Attorney Cathy Hale, representing the couple, says they were horrified and contacted Evans, who allegedly did not apologize and told them to "sue" him. The couple is now suing Premiere Photo under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied the allegations, stating there is no evidence linking the company to the offensive caption and that the couple showed no sign of mental anguish. The couple's lawyer emphasizes they want an apology at the very least, and mediation is scheduled, with a potential trial in July if an agreement is not reached.

Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach in recovering from his latest concussion, remaining unsure when he will return after pulling out of a Harlequins Aviva Premiership clash. He is determined not to rush back to avoid an extended break, citing the risks of getting into a situation like Johnny Sexton's 12-week absence. Brown emphasizes the importance of increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by World Rugby online modules, which helped him realize he wasn't ready to face Ireland. He also mentions that this awareness is crucial for players to be honest about their conditions and not risk playing on if showing symptoms.

Smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sex among couples, as suggested by a leading expert. Research indicates that the number of times Britons are having sex has been decreasing since the emergence of the internet, with a typical heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, attributes this decline to increased technological connectivity, which has blurred boundaries between public and private lives, making people busier and reducing quiet time. This constant connectivity, such as checking emails, leads to competing demands on time, causing sex to fall down the priority list and making it difficult to focus on partners at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly valued and even commanding prices up to £1.2 million, are now so unpopular in China that they are being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots. This decline is partly blamed on the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made people hesitant to give or receive the dogs as gifts. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities have impacted the breed's popularity. The market collapse was revealed after animal-welfare workers rescued dogs en route to a slaughterhouse, finding them in cramped cages with many dead or suffering. Unscrupulous breeders and theft by gangs are also contributing to the dogs being sent to abattoirs. The breed's boom began in 2005, with the dogs seen as status symbols, but now there is a glut of poor-quality dogs that can't be sold.

Every woman surveyed in Paris claimed to have been a victim of some kind of sexual harassment on the city's public transport, with half of them assaulted before they were 18 years old. The harassment ranges from insults and intimidating behavior to sex attacks or rape, often going unreported and limiting women's freedom by obligating them to alter their daily lives. The issue has led to calls for a campaign to stem sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains, as it excludes women from the public arena. The report emphasizes that women must be able to move about and occupy public space without danger or threat, highlighting the need for education that what they experience is not normal and that actions like putting a hand on someone's backside are punishable by law.

Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to address common everyday emergencies, asking groups to design products for these issues. Three shortlisted prototypes include Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to help with not being able to sleep; Forget Me Lock, a device that shows if a door is locked by swiveling green for open and red for locked; and Nipper, the world's smallest mobile phone charger using household batteries. The public can vote by retweeting tweets about these products, with the winner going into a Kickstarter campaign. Other ideas, like a parking pin and a relay app, didn't make the final shortlist.

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is facing a Ministry of Justice investigation after awarding over half a million pounds of public money to a charity she runs, Victims First Northumbria, which supports crime victims in her area. Sitting alongside her on the organization's top table is Sue Sim, Northumbria's chief constable. Critics accuse them of creating a "soap opera" within the force, calling Baird's selection of the charity inappropriate and a conflict of interest. The funds were allocated following a rule allowing police and crime commissioners to commission services for victims, with Baird boasting about securing the funds on the charity's website. A Ministry of Justice spokesman confirmed the investigation to determine if any conflict of interest rules were broken.

Three people have been sent to prison and another two are awaiting sentencing for their roles in a horrific assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, was the ringleader of the gang dubbed 'tattoo terrorists,' believing Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles. The incident occurred in the basement of Campbell's mother's house, where Valecce was tortured for three days. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, cornered Valecce, filmed the abuse, and tattooed offensive symbols on him. Valecce suffered injuries, escaped, and contacted police. All three were charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment, pleading guilty. Campbell and Halin received 20-year sentences, while Ng was sentenced to 23 months. David Thomas is awaiting sentencing, and Jennifer Pratt is awaiting trial.
